finding: The rs41264915-A variant linked to MUC1 was associated with increased pulmonary function metrics, indicating a protective effect in a COVID-19 context.
title: Integration of GWAS and multi-omic QTLs identifies uncharacterized COVID-19 gene-biotype and phenotype associations

finding: The SNP rs12082223 was associated with the therapeutic response to antibody-drug conjugates in ovarian cancer, as discussed in the context of Epithelial Ovarian Cancer (EOC). This relationship was highlighted in the study featuring patients with FRα-expressing tumors, indicating a potential predictive value of this SNP in the therapeutic outcomes and efficacy of novel treatments.
title: Folate receptor alpha protein expression in ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma tumors of The Cancer Genome Atlas: exploration beyond single-agent therapy

finding: The rs4949677-A SNP in MSH4 was significantly associated with increased survival, where carriers of the A/A pair had a median survival time of 9.2 years, compared to 12.8 and 14.4 years for A/T and T/T carriers, respectively.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: The G allele of rs3219489 in MUTYH was suggestively associated with increased survival times; carriers had median survival times of 16.9 years compared to 11.3 years for C/C genotype carriers.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: SNP rs5745366-T in MSH4 was suggestively associated with improved survival (HR=0.33), where carriers of the C/T genotype had a median survival of 13.6 years compared to 9.5 years for C/C genotype carriers.
title: The impact of germline variants in DNA repair pathways on survival and temozolomide toxicity in adults with glioma

finding: The rs4844610 SNP in the CR1 locus was noted as a significant marker in a large PAD CSF-PET meta-analysis (P=5.76e-18), associating it with AD and amyloid endophenotypes.
title: Connecting genomic and proteomic signatures of amyloid burden in the brain

finding: The SNP rs121908309 was identified as a heterozygous stop-gain variant p.R398* in one patient. This finding was part of the assessment of the full landscape of GBA-related parkinsonism, highlighting the importance of GBA variants as a major genetic risk factor for Parkinson's disease.
title: Accurate long-read sequencing identified GBA variants as a major genetic risk factor in the Luxembourg Parkinson’s study

finding: The SNP rs2230288 was found in two patients as a homozygous missense variant p.E365K/p.E365K. This variant contributed to the understanding of the genetic landscape related to GBA and its association with Parkinson's disease.
title: Accurate long-read sequencing identified GBA variants as a major genetic risk factor in the Luxembourg Parkinson’s study

finding: The SNP rs138498426 was identified as a splice site variant p.T408T, which is located within 2bp of the exon boundary and categorized as a variant of unknown significance (VUS). This classification aided in the assessment of the potential risk prediction for GBA-related parkinsonism.
title: Accurate long-read sequencing identified GBA variants as a major genetic risk factor in the Luxembourg Parkinson’s study

finding: The SNP rs3176466 near CDKN2C was found to have a significant association with FVC, P=4.59x10^-8 and a beta of 0.0236, contributing to the understanding of lung function traits.
title: Multi-trait and multi-ancestry genetic analysis of comorbid lung diseases and traits improves genetic discovery and polygenic risk prediction

finding: The rs188468174 SNP, located at the RUNX3 locus on chr.1p36.11, exhibited a significant positive correlation with serum IgA levels (Beta=0.88, P=3.42×10^-92). It was previously associated with IgA levels and IgG glycosylation. The minor allele was linked to lower IgA levels and increased RUNX3 expression.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: The rs7518129 SNP at the TNFSF4 locus on chr.1q25.1 demonstrated a strong association with IgA levels (Beta=0.06, P=1.06×10^-16) and was previously linked to immune responses relevant to allergic conditions.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: The analysis of SNP rs12142220 was part of a combined linkage study that produced a maximum combined multipoint logarithm of odds (LOD) score of 2.98, indicating a strong association with Oculopharyngodistal myopathy (OPDM) in two Australian families. This SNP was located within the studied linkage region of approximately 24 Mb, suggesting its relevance in the genetic underpinnings of OPDM.
title: A CCG expansion in ABCD3 causes oculopharyngodistal myopathy in individuals of European ancestry

finding: SNP rs490680 was included in the linkage analysis that achieved a maximum combined multipoint logarithm of odds (LOD) score of 2.98, which suggested a significant association with OPDM. The study highlighted its inclusion in the linkage region spanning chr1: 84,662,217 – 108,724,518, further implicating it in the genetics of the disease.
title: A CCG expansion in ABCD3 causes oculopharyngodistal myopathy in individuals of European ancestry

finding: SNP rs1801265 was identified as the point at which the maximum combined multipoint logarithm of odds (LOD) score of 2.98 was achieved in the genetic linkage analysis. This finding reinforced its importance in the study of Oculopharyngodistal myopathy (OPDM) within the linkage region characterized by CCG repeat expansions in the ABCD3 gene.
title: A CCG expansion in ABCD3 causes oculopharyngodistal myopathy in individuals of European ancestry

finding: rs147138607 was identified as an intergenic variant between CACNA1E and ZNF648, associated with an increased risk of incident cardiovascular disease (CVD) in people with type 2 diabetes (T2D), with a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.23, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.15 – 1.32, and p-value 3.6×10^-9, reaching genome-wide significance.
title: Time-to-Event Genome-Wide Association Study for Incident Cardiovascular Disease in People with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

finding: SNP rs764862951 was associated with known cardiomyopathies, specifically linked to the TNNT gene.
title: Deep representation learning of electrocardiogram reveals novel insights in cardiac structure and functions and connections to cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP at 1q25.2 (rs61824368) was highlighted as a novel finding in connection with both schizophrenia and depression.
title: Multi-trait genetic analysis identifies novel pleiotropic loci for depression and SCZ in East Asians

finding: At the LEPR locus, rs10493377 demonstrated a significant peak association for BMI development specific to early childhood, characterized by a transient association profile.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: The TNNI3K variant rs10493544 demonstrated a strong relationship with childhood BMI, peaking around two years of age, within the Early Rise cluster.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: SEC16B variant rs545608 was included in the Late Rise cluster, where it maintained associations with BMI into childhood and adulthood.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: At the LEPR locus, the intronic variant rs2767486 was found to have the strongest overall association with BMI across childhood, peaking at six months.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: The intronic variant rs10889551 near LEPR represented a significant novel finding driving BMI associations early in childhood.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: The SNP rs12071784 was associated with response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy in muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC). The study indicated that tumors classified as Genomically Unstable (GU) and Urothelial-like (Uro) subtypes, which likely involve this SNP, showed higher proportions of pathological response and better survival outcomes compared to the Basal-Squamous (Ba/Sq) subtype when treated with cisplatin-based chemotherapy. This finding highlighted the potential importance of genomic markers in predicting chemotherapy efficacy.
title: Different responses to neoadjuvant chemotherapy in urothelial carcinoma molecular subtypes

finding: The rs11118133 polymorphism, which governs CR1 density on erythrocytes (E), was analyzed in 52 COVID-19 patients. It was determined that although the expected genotypes (HH, HL, LL) were similarly represented in patients and controls, the CR1/E density (expressed as CR1/E%) exhibited a decrease across all genotypes in COVID-19 patients. Importantly, this decrease was independent of the genetic inheritance indicated by rs11118133, suggesting that the observed changes in CR1 density were acquired and related to the severity of COVID-19, particularly among individuals with the high-density HH genotype. The findings indicative of significant CR1 receptor loss and increased C4d deposits on E highlighted a potential link between genetic factors at rs11118133 and acquired complement system dysregulation in COVID-19.
title: Acquired decrease of the C3b/C4b receptor (CR1, CD35) and increased C4d deposits on Erythrocytes from ICU COVID-19 Patients

finding: The SNP rs1969869 was associated with DNA methylation levels at the 1q21.1 DMR, exhibiting a strong effect (genotype vs methylation estimate = 0.19, p < 10^-13) in both blood and brain tissues from primary progressive MS patients. This suggested its critical role in mediating genetic control of DNA methylation at this locus.
title: Implication of DNA methylation changes at chromosome 1q21.1 in the brain pathology of Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis

finding: Similar to rs1969869, the SNP rs4950357 also displayed a positive association with CpG methylation levels, passing Bonferroni correction for significance (p < 10^-8). This SNP was part of the same extended locus and contributed to the regulation of DNA methylation in relation to primary progressive MS.
title: Implication of DNA methylation changes at chromosome 1q21.1 in the brain pathology of Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis

finding: The T allele at rs509325 was associated with multiple phenotypes, showing a decrease in age at adiposity peak (AP) by -0.003 years (P=1×10⁻⁸) and an increase in age at adiposity rebound (AR) by 0.12 years (P=5×10⁻¹⁶). It was also linked to a decrease in BMI at the AR by -0.08 kg/m² (P=5×10⁻⁸) and reductions in early and late childhood slopes.
title: A framework for conducting time-varying genome-wide association studies: An application to body mass index across childhood in six multiethnic cohorts

finding: This SNP was identified as a novel shared locus between ADHD and ASD. It was part of a highly pleiotropic multigene locus on chromosome 1, highlighting its potential relevance in the genetic architecture of both disorders.
title: Identification of shared and differentiating genetic risk for autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and case subgroups

finding: This SNP on chromosome 1 was associated with increased risk for ASD and cognitive performance, while the ADHD risk allele conferred decreased performance. It was among the significant SNPs correlated with educational attainment.
title: Identification of shared and differentiating genetic risk for autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and case subgroups

finding: For the DFFB locus, the lead SNP rs74752626 had a p-value of 5.14e-281, making it one of the major findings in the cfGWAS study, confirming its importance in cfDNA biology.
title: cfGWAS reveal genetic basis of cell-free DNA features

finding: In the independent replication cohort, the SNP rs35265408 for the DFFB locus showed a p-value of 7.07e-13, confirming its association with cfDNA features despite its removal from the discovery study due to Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium filtration.
title: cfGWAS reveal genetic basis of cell-free DNA features

finding: The alternate allele of rs1050316, located in the 3' UTR of MEF2D, was associated with a substantial decrease in pain risk (OR=0.34, 95%CI=0.28-0.41, P=6.2e-29). This SNP was previously associated with decreased expression of MEF2D, and the analysis indicated that its effect might be mediated by decreased platelet count and volume, highlighting its influence on immune function.
title: GWAS meta-analysis reveals dual neuronal and immunological etiology for pain susceptibility

finding: The alternate allele of rs13294, which encodes a missense variant in ECM1, was associated with decreased pain risk (P=1.4e-13). It was linked to decreased blood protein levels and is expressed in macrophages, emphasizing its role in regulating inflammatory states in the context of chronic pain.
title: GWAS meta-analysis reveals dual neuronal and immunological etiology for pain susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs61775569 was identified as genome-wide significant and was associated with multiple phenotypic factors related to neurodevelopmental traits. This association was part of a study exploring genetic liabilities and phenotypic correlations in children.
title: Genetic and phenotypic heterogeneity in early neurodevelopmental traits in the Norwegian Mother, Father and Child Cohort Study

finding: The SNP rs5779595 showed a significant association with neck or shoulder pain in the female-specific GWAS, with a p-value of 3.57 x 10^-8, located near the LINC02770 gene on chromosome 1. This indicates a potential genetic influence specific to females regarding pain susceptibility.
title: A Genome-wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Neck or Shoulder Pain in the UK Biobank (N = 441,757)

finding: The SNP rs570516915 was strongly associated with isolated cleft palate (CP) in the Finnish population. Its association was significant (P = 5.25 x 10-34, OR = 8.65), demonstrating a robust connection to CP risk, while there was no significant association with cleft lip with or without cleft palate (CL/P). This SNP disrupted a conserved binding site for the transcription factor IRF6, leading to decreased enhancer activity upstream of the IRF6 gene and reduced expression levels of IRF6.
title: High incidence and geographic distribution of cleft palate cases in Finland are associated with a regulatory variant in IRF6

finding: The lead isoQTL rs2125232 exhibited a strong positive effect on the isoform ENST00000492957 of the gene AKT3. The association with schizophrenia was notable, despite the eQTL indicating a weak signal, thus directing attention to isoforms rather than total gene expression.
title: Isoform-level transcriptome-wide association uncovers extensive novel genetic risk mechanisms for neuropsychiatric disorders in the human brain

finding: Like rs2113389, SNP rs429328 was associated with cortical tau levels in Alzheimer’s disease, contributing to the overall modulation of tau-related pathology.
title: Novel CYP1B1-RMDN2 Alzheimer’s disease locus identified by genome-wide association analysis of cerebral tau deposition on PET

finding: SNP rs116089225 was associated with a significant increased risk of glaucoma (OR=1.70) and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), indicating its role in these phenotypes as a positive and original finding.
title: Repeat polymorphisms in non-coding DNA underlie top genetic risk loci for glaucoma and colorectal cancer

finding: The intronic SNP rs2235370 of TRAF3IP3 was previously reported as a sentinel variant associated with the risk of cleft lip with or without cleft palate (CL/P) in prior GWAS cross-ancestry meta-analysis. The study presented strong evidence of differential expression (DE) of genetically predicted expression of TRAF3IP3 related to CL/P risk (cross-ancestry P = 2.0©10^-12). The DE remained highly significant (cross-ancestry P = 6.5©10^-13) when assessed only based on 8 linked SNPs with rs2235370.
title: Estimation of Direct and Indirect Polygenic Effects and Gene-Environment Interactions using Polygenic Scores in Case-Parent Trio Studies

finding: The SNP rs74538320 was associated with PPP risk and showed evidence of pleiotropy, affecting the expression of the FCGR3B gene. This result, with a statistical significance (pSMR=5.3x10^-6), indicated a potential role in the disease mechanism of PPP.
title: A genome-wide meta-analysis of palmoplantar pustulosis implicates Th2 responses and cigarette smoking in disease pathogenesis

finding: The FCGR2A rs1801274 GG genotype was notably associated with an increased likelihood of experiencing symptomatic events during follow-up, affirming its role as a prognostic biomarker in CCM.
title: Genetic Markers and Predictive Factors Influencing the Aggressive Behavior of Cerebral Cavernous Malformation

finding: The SNP rs3791033, which is an intronic variant of KDM4A, was associated with problematic opioid use (POU) in a GWAS involving 132,113 participants. It was reported with a genome-wide significance p-value of 3.80E-08. Previous studies had implicated rs3791033 in various traits including smoking phenotypes, ADHD, and educational attainment, indicating its relevance to both addictive behaviors and cognitive outcomes.
title: Genome-wide association study of problematic opioid prescription use in 132,113 23andMe research participants of European ancestry

finding: The SNP rs640561, an intergenic variant near LRRIQ3, also reached genome-wide significance with a p-value of 3.80E-08 in relation to POU. It showed nominal associations with vulnerabilities related to neurological and psychiatric traits, such as ADHD, reflecting potential wider implications in mental health disorders, although further details regarding the strength of these associations were not highlighted.
title: Genome-wide association study of problematic opioid prescription use in 132,113 23andMe research participants of European ancestry

finding: The SNP rs35749011, associated with the GBA p.E326K variant, showed an association with mortality (p=3.6×10^-4) and cognitive impairment (p=0.02) in Parkinson's disease despite not causing Gaucher disease.
title: Genome-wide determinants of mortality and clinical progression in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs12037951 was highlighted as a vQTL with a significant main effect on the protein levels of ACP6. This finding established rs12037951 as both a positive and original discovery in relation to protein level modulation.
title: Systematic discovery of gene-environment interactions underlying the human plasma proteome in UK Biobank

finding: The analysis revealed that rs190188611 significantly impacted the causal inference of lymphocyte FSC-A parameters, highlighting its importance in immune characterization.
title: Causal effect of the gut microbiota on the risk of psychiatric disorders and the mediating role of immunophenotypes

finding: In the study, rs12041621 was found to significantly drive the causal inferences of <italic>R. bromii</italic> on the level of CD33 on basophils, thus influencing immune characteristics.
title: Causal effect of the gut microbiota on the risk of psychiatric disorders and the mediating role of immunophenotypes

finding: The C allele of rs2228145 was significantly associated with decreased risk of tuberculosis (TB) disease, evidenced by a summary odds ratio (OR) of 0.94, indicating that each additional C allele was correlated with a lower likelihood of developing TB. Furthermore, Mendelian randomisation analyses using this SNP demonstrated that reduced classical IL-6 activity, as measured by CRP levels, significantly contributed to a lower risk of TB disease development. The finding reflects the broader implications of IL-6 signalling in TB susceptibility and suggests a potential therapeutic avenue using IL-6 antagonists.
title: Altered IL-6 signalling and risk of tuberculosis disease: a meta-analysis and Mendelian randomisation study

finding: The SNP at the NPPB-RNU5E-1 locus confirmed its role concerning 5-methyltetrahydrofolate levels, with a significant p-value of 9.49x10-15.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: This SNP was associated with magnesium levels, indicating a genetic influence on this trace element.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The study reported that all 15 patients with the homozygous rs7542235 GG genotype had varying sizes of deletions that encompassed the entire CFHR1 gene. This deletion was confirmed through multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) and whole genome sequencing (WGS), highlighting the primary role of the CFHR1 gene in relation to kidney transplant rejection. The presence of the GG genotype was associated with increased risk for acute rejection, with 53% of these patients experiencing rejection compared to only 19% among those with heterozygous (AG) or homozygous non-deletion (AA) genotypes. The findings indicated that the absence of CFHR1 protein in the plasma of these patients correlated with alterations in levels of 23 different proteins involved in pathways related to alloimmune response, further emphasizing the impact of the CFHR3-1 deletion on transplantation outcomes.
title: Gene deletions in complement factor H related protein gene locus and kidney transplantation

finding: The rs581342 SNP at the LMNA locus was linked to neutropenia with an odds ratio of 1.29 (p=4.1 x 10^-13) among African ancestry individuals, revealing significant ethnic variations in its association with severe COVID-19 outcomes, but not seen in European descent.
title: A Phenome-Wide Association Study of genes associated with COVID-19 severity reveals shared genetics with complex diseases in the Million Veteran Program

finding: rs12075 demonstrated associations with multiple chemokines (CCL2, CCL7, CCL8) and white blood cell counts, with DARC as a candidate mediator.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: The SNP rs301799 was associated with total log acceleration (TLA) between 6pm to 8pm, indicating its role in early evening activity. This finding underscored a connection between physical activity patterns and the central nervous system's mediation of genetic effects.
title: Genome-wide association studies of 27 accelerometry-derived physical activity measurements identifies novel loci and genetic mechanisms

finding: SNP rs1144566 was found to be associated with sleep proxy phenotypes, specifically involving timing of least active periods and various TLA measures during night hours.
title: Genome-wide association studies of 27 accelerometry-derived physical activity measurements identifies novel loci and genetic mechanisms

finding: The rs74113753 variant was identified as an African-specific missense variant associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). It was reported that this variant shares significant statistical association with the rs111739240 variant, indicating that both variants are contributing to POAG prevalence in African populations.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs17641032 variant, a proxy for rs74113753, demonstrated association with primary open-angle glaucoma in African ancestry populations. This variant was involved in expressing the TMEM167B gene, highlighting its role in the genetic risk for POAG among African populations.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs74315329 variation was associated with primary open-angle glaucoma exclusively in European ancestry populations, illustrating its specific significance in this ancestry which was supported by existing literature.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs1469837390 variant was newly defined and showed differential effects in Finnish and EstBB populations. It presented a strong association with primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating its relevance to glaucoma genetics in Northern European populations.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs147660927 variant was newly defined and implied to be associated with primary open-angle glaucoma, particularly in Northern European populations, enhancing the understanding of population-specific genetic risks.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs111739240 variant was identified as African-specific and is in perfect linkage disequilibrium with the rs74113753 missense variant, indicating that it contributes to POAG risk and was found to have potential damaging effects.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The rs993471 variant was reaffirmed as a common risk locus intersecting with POAG and PACG, demonstrating shared genetic underpinnings across these subtypes.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: This SNP in the intron of CHI3L1 was primarily associated with the non-AD inflammation component (PC4), showing a strong negative association with scores (-0.39SD). It was also nominally associated with injury/inflammation (PC3).
title: Multivariate GWAS of Alzheimer’s disease CSF biomarker profiles implies GRIN2D in synaptic functioning

finding: This SNP was associated with decreased odds of neonatal sepsis, with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.74. It was located near the transcription start site of the IL10 gene in a strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) block with rs1800871 (r2 = 0.9), reinforcing the role of IL10 in susceptibility to late-onset neonatal sepsis.
title: Genetic study of late-onset neonatal sepsis reveals significant differences by sex

finding: Similar to rs1518111, this SNP was associated with decreased odds of neonatal sepsis, presenting an odds ratio (OR) of 0.69. Positioned near the transcription start site of the IL10 gene and in strong LD with rs1518111 (r2 = 0.9), it underscored the significance of IL10 in late-onset neonatal sepsis susceptibility.
title: Genetic study of late-onset neonatal sepsis reveals significant differences by sex

finding: This SNP was associated with increased odds of neonatal sepsis (OR 1.47), and was located in an LD block with the other 3' SNPs. This association indicated a risk factor for LOS, emphasizing the complex relationships in the IL10 gene region.
title: Genetic study of late-onset neonatal sepsis reveals significant differences by sex

finding: Associating with increased odds of neonatal sepsis (OR 1.60), this SNP also belonged to the same LD block as rs55705316 and rs3024493. This finding supported the increased risk associated with these SNPs in the context of late-onset neonatal sepsis.
title: Genetic study of late-onset neonatal sepsis reveals significant differences by sex

finding: Identified with increased odds of neonatal sepsis (OR 1.50), this SNP was in linkage disequilibrium with rs55705316 and rs3024505. The consistent association across these SNPs in the same LD structure highlighted their collective relevance in LOS susceptibility.
title: Genetic study of late-onset neonatal sepsis reveals significant differences by sex

finding: Variant rs2227624 was a known missense variant causing a Val to Glu amino-acid substitution, which led to antithrombin deficiency and increased the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE). This variant was significant in previous studies.
title: Antithrombin, protein C and protein S: Genome and transcriptome wide association studies identify 7 novel loci regulating plasma levels

finding: This intronic variant in GPX7 exhibited strong eQTL significance in the aorta and was also associated with ascending aortic distensibility.
title: GENOME-WIDE ASSOCIATIONS OF AORTIC DISTENSIBILITY SUGGEST CAUSAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH AORTIC ANEURYSMS AND BRAIN WHITE MATTER HYPERINTENSITIES

finding: The ARID1A variant rs114165349 demonstrated significant associations with lipid levels, particularly affecting IDL and LDL particles, while showing negative effects on HDL particles.
title: Exploring metabolic changes in gout – Insights from a genetic study

finding: The SNP rs34517439 from DNAJB4 was identified as significantly associated with lung cancer in the multi-ancestry GWAS meta-analysis, marking it as an important variant in cancer risk studies.
title: Multi-trait and multi-ancestry genetic analysis of comorbid lung diseases and traits improves genetic discovery and polygenic risk prediction

finding: The SNP rs4950119 was identified as a highly influential outlier variant affecting the relationship between schizophrenia-specific genetic components (SZspecific) and educational attainment (EA). Initially, SZspecific was shown to have no significant association with EA (IVW: β = -0.016, p = 0.08). However, after the removal of rs4950119, the relationship became significant (IVW: β = -0.021, p = 0.01), indicating a stronger negative association between SZspecific and EA. This finding highlighted the importance of rs4950119 in influencing the genetic correlation with educational attainment.
title: Splitting Schizophrenia: Divergent Cognitive and Educational Outcomes Revealed by Genomic Structural Equation Modelling

finding: The variant rs3766405, located in the CFH locus, was associated with advanced AMD with significant heterogeneity between ancestries. It showed positive association in EUR and Asian (ASN) populations (OR ranged between 1.76 to 2.67), but not in AFR (OR=1.23, 95% CI [0.79, 1.90]).
title: Diverse ancestry GWAS for advanced age-related macular degeneration in TOPMed-imputed and Ophthalmologically-confirmed 16,108 cases and 18,038 controls

finding: The study found a strong genetic association between rs2228145 and abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) risk. This missense variant was associated with a lower risk of AAA per additional copy of the C allele, evidenced by odds ratios of 0.91 in the AAAgen consortium and 0.90 in the UK Biobank. The results indicated a linear association based on the number of minor alleles, translating to a protective effect against AAA, consistent with interleukin-6 (IL6) signaling inhibition.
title: Human genetic evidence to inform clinical development of interleukin-6 signaling inhibition for abdominal aortic aneurysm

finding: This SNP from PARK16 achieved significance (P-value=0.01) in the penetrance model, marking it as a positive finding related to LRRK2 mutations.
title: Genome-wide association studies of LRRK2 modifiers of Parkinson’s disease

finding: The missense variant rs777251055 in NCF2 was identified in 2.8% of a cohort representing congenital obstructive uropathy. It was associated with kidney anomalies such as renal hypoplasia and cystic renal dysplasia, although the statistical association signal was attenuated when conditioning on this variant.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals contribution of rare and common variation to structural kidney and urinary tract malformations

finding: The SNP rs775103516 was associated with increased levels of pancreas fat, which in turn was linked to a higher risk of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). After adjusting for other variables, the odds ratio indicated a significant association.
title: Genetic Evidence Causally Linking Pancreas Fat to Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: This proxy SNP for rs775103516 was found to have a strong association with pancreas fat levels, which suggested a significant role in the risk of PDAC.
title: Genetic Evidence Causally Linking Pancreas Fat to Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: As a newly recognized shared genetic risk SNP, rs4487979 demonstrated the genetic interplay between MS and BMI in the study.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: The study found a significant association of rs2476601 (PTPN22) with ME/CFS patients, particularly in cases potentially triggered by an acute infection. The estimated allele-related odds ratio for this SNP was 1.63 [95%CI = (1.04, 2.55)], indicating a potential risk factor.
title: Impact of imperfect diagnosis in ME/CFS association studies

finding: This SNP was associated with the odds of missingness of 3-decenoylcarnitine and identified as a metabolome QTL, suggesting its influence on the metabolism of fatty acids and potential connections to energy production processes.
title: Genome-wide Association Studies of Missing Metabolite Measures: Results From Two Population-based Studies

finding: The SNP rs12030555 was associated with alterations in carcinogenesis-related biomarkers in the Wnt pathway, as reported by Bai et al. (2020). This finding was particularly relevant to the studies of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in oral squamous cell carcinoma, indicating that the SNP may play a role in the progression of this type of cancer.
title: Lymphoid Enhancer-Binding Factor 1 (LEF1) immunostaining as a surrogate of β-catenin (CTNNB1) mutations

finding: The variant rs12407731 in EIF4G3 was found to have a noteworthy association with a P-value of 2.36×10^-8 in the analyses conducted, marking a potential novel risk factor.

The Duffy/DARC null variant (rs2814778) was strongly associated with lower circulating neutrophil and white blood cell (WBC) counts in both Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) and non-SCD individuals. In SCD patients, the variant's effect was significantly weaker, contributing only 0.9-3.3% of the variance in neutrophil counts compared to 18.4-23.1% in non-SCD individuals.
title: Variation and impact of polygenic hematological traits in monogenic sickle cell disease

finding: The rs1333973 variant, located in the IFI44L gene, did not affect the overall expression level of the IFI44L gene but exhibited opposing effects on isoform expressions. Specifically, in subjects with the A/A genotype, isoforms NM0068020.3 and XM_0115405392 showed the highest expression, while isoforms XM_005270391.3 and XM_017000120.1 had the highest expression in T/T individuals. The minigene splicing assay demonstrated that rs1333973 impacted the splicing pattern by reducing the longer transcript fragments and generating shorter fragments due to exon skipping.
title: Long-read sequencing reveals novel isoform-specific eQTLs and regulatory mechanisms of isoform expression

finding: The study confirmed the well-known association of the ACKR1 Duffy-null allele (rs2814778) with reduced neutrophil counts, achieving a significance of p = 1.06e-19 and a beta of -0.87, underscoring its relevance in hematological traits.
title: A Southern African Map of Blood Regulatory Variation Enables GWAS Interpretation

finding: In the FCGR2A/FCGR3A locus associated with COPD, the lead intergenic variant rs2099684 showed a genome-wide significant link (P = 1.7 × 10^-11) and is known for its associations with autoimmune diseases.
title: Meta-analysis fine-mapping is often miscalibrated at single-variant resolution

finding: The SNP rs11583319 was identified as a novel risk SNP associated with DENND1B, which suggested potential susceptibility to PBC and IBD. This SNP was also found to contribute to significant differences in gene expression.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs67236816 was significant in the cross-trait analysis for CD-PBC, suggesting its role in the genetic connection between these diseases.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs10752745 was identified as significant in the UC-PBC association, reflecting its potential impact on the shared genetic mechanisms underlying these conditions.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs12740041 was noted as a susceptibility gene region linked to IBD, particularly Crohn's Disease, and was relevant in the context of shared genetic influences with PBC.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs2488393 was associated with PBC susceptibility and was previously reported, showing its significance in the genetic architecture of IBD.
title: Rare Comorbidity between Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Primary Biliary Cholangitis: Evidence from Causality, Shared Genetic Architecture and Transcriptomics

finding: The variant rs17047661 in the CR1 gene was associated with FSGS, replicating its significance in Latin-American cohorts. It was previously linked to protection against cerebral malaria in sub-Saharan African populations, indicating its potential role in immune response and its effect on adaptive immunity.
title: CR1 variants contribute to FSGS susceptibility across multiple populations

finding: This variant within PARP1 was recognized for its protective effect on DNMT3A-CH, suggesting implications for targeted therapies against CH.
title: Genome-wide analyses of 200,453 individuals yields new insights into the causes and consequences of clonal hematopoiesis

finding: The SNP rs1341664 was identified as the cis-variant with the strongest association with serum amyloid P (SAP) levels. This finding was supported by meta-analysis from three genome-wide association studies involving 44,288 participants and indicated a significant correlation with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other dementias.
title: Genetic evidence for serum amyloid P component as a drug target for treatment of neurodegenerative disorders

finding: The rs2228145 variant, a known IL-6 receptor variant, was associated with abrogated risk for mortality in patients with chronic HFrEF carrying CH driver mutations. This SNP occurred in 62-65% of these patients and displayed strong linkage disequilibrium with other beneficial SNPs.
title: Interaction of inherited genetic variants in the NLRP3 inflammasome/IL-6 pathway with acquired clonal hematopoiesis to modulate mortality risk in patients with HFrEF

finding: The rs4129267 variant was shown to significantly reduce mortality risk in patients with chronic HFrEF and CH. This variant, also located in the IL-6 receptor gene, was found in strong linkage disequilibrium with rs2228145 and contributed to reduced IL-6 signaling.
title: Interaction of inherited genetic variants in the NLRP3 inflammasome/IL-6 pathway with acquired clonal hematopoiesis to modulate mortality risk in patients with HFrEF

finding: The rs4537545 SNP, located in the intron of the IL-6 receptor, was identified as significantly linked to reduced mortality in HFrEF patients with CH. It served as a proxy for IL-6 inhibition and was reported to correlate with lower circulating IL-6 levels.
title: Interaction of inherited genetic variants in the NLRP3 inflammasome/IL-6 pathway with acquired clonal hematopoiesis to modulate mortality risk in patients with HFrEF

finding: The SNP rs10801555 on chromosome 1 had a strong association with pure drusen, with an exceptionally low p-value of 6.0e-33, reaffirming its established link with age-related macular degeneration.
title: Genetic Distinctions Between Reticular Pseudodrusen and Drusen: Insights from a Genome-Wide Association Study

finding: The T allele of rs1967017 was associated with increased PDZK1 expression, which has been linked to decreased serum urate levels. This finding provided insights into the genetic mechanisms governing serum urate concentrations.
title: The individual and global impact of copy number variants on complex human traits

finding: The PDZK1 truncating variant rs191362962 correlated with decreased serum urate levels, confirming the role of PDZK1 in urate transport and metabolism.
title: The individual and global impact of copy number variants on complex human traits

finding: The expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) rs55794721 was identified as driving expression levels of both RHD and RSRP1, influencing hematological traits such as reticulocyte count and platelet count. This locus proved significant in the context of its association with hematological parameters.
title: The individual and global impact of copy number variants on complex human traits

finding: The SNP rs74315329 was identified as a stop-gain variant in the MYOC gene, known for its association with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). It exhibited a very strong significance in the study with a P-value of 1.22 × 10^-26.
title: Whole-exome sequencing study identifies novel rare variants and genes associated with intraocular pressure and glaucoma

finding: The SNP rs28991009 was found to be significant in the exome-wide association study (ExWAS) and had previously shown significance in a genome-wide association study (GWAS), indicating its continued relevance in studying intraocular pressure (IOP).
title: Whole-exome sequencing study identifies novel rare variants and genes associated with intraocular pressure and glaucoma

finding: The rs41264915 variant was implicated in the association with MUC1, suggesting a role in COVID-19 progression and critical illness.
title: Whole genome sequencing identifies multiple loci for critical illness caused by COVID-19

finding: The study by Si et al. (2020) indicated an increased level of TG/HDL-C in female carriers of the G allele of rs1061622, which was associated with suicidal ideation (SI). This finding suggested a significant genetic influence on SI, linking the tumor necrosis factor receptor 2 (TNFR2) gene to the underlying mechanisms of SI.
title: Inflammation and nitro-oxidative stress in current suicidal attempts and current suicidal ideation: a systematic review and meta-analysis

finding: The missense variant rs1166698 in the NEXN gene was highlighted as associated with cardiomyopathies, showing a significant association with clinical conditions related to heart function and structure.
title: Genetic analyses of the QT interval and its components in over 250K individuals identifies new loci and pathways affecting ventricular depolarization and repolarization

finding: The rs12042862 variant at the NOS1AP locus was associated with increased risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD), demonstrating a significant relationship and suggesting its role in heart arrhythmias in the context of QT and JT intervals.
title: Genetic analyses of the QT interval and its components in over 250K individuals identifies new loci and pathways affecting ventricular depolarization and repolarization

finding: The SNP rs1405051 demonstrated a protective interaction with rs6855309 within 1p31.1 in the context of LCL, showing an odds ratio of 0.53 with a p-value of 2.48 × 10-5. This interaction was also observed in LCLP, indicating a possible protective genetic interaction effect.
title: FAT4 Identified as a Potential Modifier of Orofacial Cleft Laterality

finding: The SNP rs12034480 was associated with increased risk for left unilateral cleft lip (LCL) only, with an odds ratio of 2.43 and a p-value of 3.89 × 10-9, suggesting that it may be relevant specifically for LCL without affecting other subtypes.
title: FAT4 Identified as a Potential Modifier of Orofacial Cleft Laterality

finding: The variant rs2476601-G in the PTPN22 gene was linked to increased risk of NMSC, with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.14 and 95% CI (1.06, 1.21). This finding is novel, as no previous association between PTPN22 and NMSC was reported.
title: Inflammatory Bowel Disease Risk Variants Are Associated with an Increased Risk of Skin Cancer

finding: The variant rs17391694-C in GIPC2/MGC27382 was associated with decreased risk of melanoma skin cancer (MSC), with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.92 and 95% CI (0.86, 0.997).
title: Inflammatory Bowel Disease Risk Variants Are Associated with an Increased Risk of Skin Cancer

finding: In the studied population, rs12079745 was associated with QTc duration, contributing to the QTc-PRS which showed an increased QTc interval. This finding was notable as the mean QTc for the top QTc-PRS quintile was 15 msec longer than the bottom quintile.
title: Genetic QT Score and Sleep Apnea as Predictors of Sudden Cardiac Death in the UK Biobank

finding: The locus associated with the lead SNP rs12730036 physically mapped to the IL6R region. It nearly reached genome-wide significance in relation to pneumonia, indicating a potential role of interleukin-6 receptor signaling in pneumonia risk.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis of pneumonia suggests a role for mucin biology and provides novel drug repurposing opportunities

finding: This SNP, located within the DOCK7 gene, showed robust evidence of colocalization, indicating a shared genetic variant across pairs of related FA traits.
title: Genome-wide association studies and multi-omics integrative analysis reveal novel loci and their molecular mechanisms for circulating polyunsaturated, monounsaturated, and saturated fatty acids

finding: The SNP rs947350 was associated with an FEV1/FVC-associated structural variant deletion (Sniffles2.DEL.6E8M0) that uniquely mapped to the gene MEGF6. The p-value for this association was 2.1×10^-16, with a MAF of 0.069. Subsequent analyses suggested a strong causal link between MEGF6 expression in skeletal muscle and heart tissue to lower FEV1/FVC measures, indicating its significance regarding respiratory health.
title: Imputation of structural variants using a multi-ancestry long-read sequencing panel enables identification of disease associations

finding: The C allele of rs7512462 was associated with greater expression of SLC26A9 in the adult pancreas, as evidenced by studies utilizing the Genotype Tissue Expression project (GTEx). Initially identified through genome-wide association studies (GWAS) focused on meconium ileus in cystic fibrosis, this SNP was also tied to lung function in more mixed findings. Some studies reported a beneficial impact of the C allele on lung function or response to CFTR-modulators like VX-770, especially in patients with specific CFTR mutations.
title: The Solute Carrier Family 26 Member 9 Is a Modifier of the Rapidly Progressing Cystic Fibrosis Associated with F508del CFTR Mutations

finding: At locus 4 (signal 4), rs2369633 was identified as a lead SNP that correlated with the expression of the gene MDM4 in melanoma risk studies. Bayesian fine-mapping indicated it to be a credible causal variant, significantly associated with melanoma risk (P=2.17 x 10^{-7}). Capture-HiC data and CRISPRi experiments also validated its regulatory connection to MDM4.
title: Mapping chromatin interactions at melanoma susceptibility loci and cell-type specific dataset integration uncovers distant gene targets of cis-regulation

finding: Also at locus 4 (signal 4), rs12119098 presented as an independent signal associated with melanoma risk, significant as an eQTL for MDM4 with a protective allele linked to higher expression (P=5.83 x 10^{-6}). This further supported the hypothesis of MDM4's role in susceptibility to melanoma.
title: Mapping chromatin interactions at melanoma susceptibility loci and cell-type specific dataset integration uncovers distant gene targets of cis-regulation

finding: This SNP at locus 4 (signal 4) was involved in CRISPRi tests that confirmed its significant regulation of MDM4, thus validating its role in melanoma risk.
title: Mapping chromatin interactions at melanoma susceptibility loci and cell-type specific dataset integration uncovers distant gene targets of cis-regulation

finding: The SNP rs1339882991 was positively correlated with both persistence and adherence to blood pressure (BP) medications. This association aligns with previous reports indicating rs1339882991's positive correlation with hypertension, suggesting its relevance in pharmacological treatment adherence.
title: Socio-demographic and genetic risk factors for drug adherence and persistence: a retrospective nation-wide and biobank study across 5 medication classes and 1 814 521 individuals

finding: This SNP, rs3128125, located within the AGRN gene, emerged as the only independent SNP associated with MG after conducting gene-based analyses. The association was found after correcting for multiple tests, with a significant p-value of 2.78×10^-6, establishing AGRN as a novel susceptibility gene for MG.
title: A Myasthenia Gravis genomewide association study of three cohorts identifies Agrin as a novel risk locus

finding: SNP rs12057769, located in C4BPA, was significant in relation to C4 protein regulation, supporting its biological relevance.
title: The genetic and phenotypic correlates of neonatal Complement Component 3 and 4 protein concentrations with a focus on psychiatric and autoimmune disorders

finding: SNP rs558103 encoded Complement Factor H, crucial for regulating the alternative pathway of complement activation, indicating its relevance to C3 protein concentration.
title: The genetic and phenotypic correlates of neonatal Complement Component 3 and 4 protein concentrations with a focus on psychiatric and autoimmune disorders

finding: SNP rs11580821 also encoded Complement Factor H and was linked to phenotypic variance in C3 concentration, affirming its role in immune regulation.
title: The genetic and phenotypic correlates of neonatal Complement Component 3 and 4 protein concentrations with a focus on psychiatric and autoimmune disorders

finding: The SNP rs1296721356 was identified as a statistically significant interaction variant for ascorbic acid 2 sulfate, and it was noted that this finding contributes to the understanding of gene-metabolite associations related to vitamin C.
title: Effect modification by sex of genetic associations of vitamin C related metabolites in the Canadian Longitudinal Study on Aging

finding: The SNP rs1301173408 was also found to be a statistically significant interaction variant associated with ascorbic acid 2 sulfate, highlighting its role in metabolic pathways influenced by genetic factors.
title: Effect modification by sex of genetic associations of vitamin C related metabolites in the Canadian Longitudinal Study on Aging

finding: The rs855865 SNP was associated with neural speech work (NSW) in the Cleveland Family Speech and Reading study (CFSRS) with a p-value of 7x10^-6. Additionally, it was associated with vocabulary measured by WISC-V in the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC) with a p-value of 0.01. Furthermore, this SNP was linked to a methylation quantitative trait locus (meQTL) rs12124059 for methylation marker cg07196514, which also showed an association with NSW (p=0.018).
title: Association between genes regulating neural pathways for quantitative traits of speech and language disorders

finding: The rs12124059 SNP served as a meQTL for the methylation marker cg07196514, showing a significant association (p=4x10^-8). Furthermore, this methylation marker was linked with NSW, adding to the evidence of its role in speech sound disorders.
title: Association between genes regulating neural pathways for quantitative traits of speech and language disorders

finding: The independent high-risk variant rs3814316 was highlighted as a likely causal variant for disease association at the MUC1 locus, showing significant regulatory potential and a higher CADD score than rs2070803.
title: Locus-specific stratification and prioritization unveil high risk genes underlying hyperuricemia

finding: The SNP rs2297480, a local-eQTL associated with RUSC1-AS1, strongly colocalized with overall breast cancer risk in non-cancerous breast tissue. RUSC1-AS1 was evidenced to silence genes through epigenetic signaling and was correlated with breast cancer progression, indicating its role in the etiology of breast cancer.
title: Distal gene regulation mediated by non-coding RNAs contributes to germline risk for breast and prostate cancer

finding: The SNP rs2075571, which represents a distal-eQTL for SH2B1, also significantly colocalized with overall breast cancer risk in non-cancerous breast tissue. SH2B1 is known for its involvement in cytokine signaling related to cell proliferation and migration, further implicating this genetic variant in breast cancer susceptibility.
title: Distal gene regulation mediated by non-coding RNAs contributes to germline risk for breast and prostate cancer

finding: The rs590787 SNP in the RHD gene was utilized to categorize individuals as either RhD-positive or -negative within the Milieu Interieur cohort. A significant finding revealed that, in males, there were over 30 differentially expressed genes between RhD-positive and RhD-negative individuals, with enhanced IFNγ signaling observed among males who were RhD-negative. This targeted analysis suggested a potential mechanism for the previously noted increased viral resistance in RhD-negative individuals.
title: Rhesus negative males have an enhanced IFNγ-mediated immune response to influenza A virus

finding: The rs1061170 SNP in the CFH gene was associated with increased risk for overall advanced AMD with an odds ratio of 3.53 (P < 0.0001). This finding highlighted the significance of this variant in the development of advanced age-related macular degeneration (AAMD).
title: Rare Dysfunctional Complement Factor I Genetic Variants and Progression to Advanced Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: The rs121913059 SNP in the CFH gene also showed a significant association with increased risk for overall advanced AMD, having an odds ratio of 3.53 (P < 0.0001). This finding indicated a strong connection with the progression of AAMD in the studied population.
title: Rare Dysfunctional Complement Factor I Genetic Variants and Progression to Advanced Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: The variant rs2120461 was identified as a cis-gene regulator for RERE, which mediated a trans-regulatory effect on AUTS2 expression. This regulatory relationship was shown to colocalize with genetic risk for schizophrenia, suggesting its role in neurodevelopmental processes and potential contribution to schizophrenia susceptibility.
title: Single-Nucleus Atlas of Cell-Type Specific Genetic Regulation in the Human Brain

finding: The SNP rs12061409 was one of the 139 CRC-related risk variants included in the polygenic risk score (PRS) for colorectal cancer (CRC). The PRS was derived from genome-wide association studies specifically targeting individuals of European ancestry, and its accurate assessment contributed to understanding CRC risk and mortality, particularly in terms of calculating risk advancement periods (RAPs) by sex.
title: Using risk advancement periods to derive starting ages of colorectal cancer screening according to sex and polygenic risk score: Results from the UK Biobank

finding: Located 365 bp from RBBP4 at the 1p35.1 locus, the SNP had a discovery p-value of 3.32×10−7 and maintained suggestive significance in the meta-analysis (p = 1.87×10−6), indicating it may specifically increase risk for ASD.
title: Genome-wide association studies of Down syndrome associated congenital heart defects

finding: The lead SNP rs2479868 found at the SPTA1 locus was associated with spleen iron, with a beta of -0.083 and a p-value of 2.5e-22. This SNP was shown to reside in the 3' untranslated region of SPTA1, indicating potential regulatory roles in the context of erythrocyte structure.
title: Analysis of MRI-derived spleen iron in the UK Biobank identifies genetic variation linked to iron homeostasis and erythrocyte morphology

finding: The SNP rs1061170 in the CFH gene was one of the first common genetic risk factors significantly associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), contributing to 17% of AMD risk.
title: A Proteogenomic Signature of Age-related Macular Degeneration in Blood

finding: The intronic variant rs1410996 at chromosome 1q31.3 was noted for its independent association with AMD alongside rs1061170, together accounting for 17% of AMD risk.
title: A Proteogenomic Signature of Age-related Macular Degeneration in Blood

finding: In the AGES-RS study, the AMD-associated variant rs10922109 was significantly linked to AMD (P = 2.6 x 10^-16) and influenced the levels of 40 serum proteins related to AMD severity.
title: A Proteogenomic Signature of Age-related Macular Degeneration in Blood

finding: The rs570618 variant in the CFH gene was associated with AMD risk and controlled 217 different serum proteins, influencing several proteins also regulated by rs10922109.
title: A Proteogenomic Signature of Age-related Macular Degeneration in Blood

finding: The SNP rs12040957 was associated with differential radiotherapy outcomes in glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) compared to lower grade glioma (LGG). The analysis highlighted that variations at this locus contributed to the regulation of pathways related to programmed cell death and DNA repair, which may impact survival outcomes in patients undergoing radiotherapy.
title: Variability in Radiotherapy Outcomes Across Cancer Types: A Comparative Study of Glioblastoma Multiforme and Low-Grade Gliomas

finding: The SNP rs2310819 was noted for its involvement in genetic networks that encapsulate both PTSD susceptibility and cardiovascular conditions.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs340874 was confirmed to display colocalization with PTSD, linking it to health behavior and cardiovascular outcomes.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs11581459 was identified as part of the significant findings linking PTSD to cardiovascular disease mechanisms.
title: Genetics of posttraumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular conditions using Life’s Essential 8, Electronic Health Records, and Heart Imaging

finding: The SNP rs142709330 found on the 1q41 locus was highlighted during the multi-trait colocalization analysis as a significant variant shared between MDD, MI, and quantitative traits of blood lipids, further supporting its pleiotropic nature.
title: Role of Blood Lipids in the Shared Genetic Etiology Between Major Depressive Disorder and Myocardial Infarction: A Large-scale Multi-trait Association Analysis

finding: SNP rs2165870 had an alternate G allele frequency of approximately 70% in the Japanese population. The study confirmed that all five participants possessed the G allele, aligning with previous observations of this SNP's relevance to perioperative outcomes.
title: Rapid detection of single nucleotide polymorphisms using the MinION nanopore sequencer: a feasibility study for perioperative precision medicine

finding: The SNP rs72641067 at 1p36.22 showed a P-value of 7.4×10−3 and OR of 1.47, marking it as an autoimmune relevant gene, associated with CD as per prior findings.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The SNP rs773646156, located at the 1p36.13 locus, had a suggestive significance level with a P-value of 4.53×10−7 and OR of 1.33, confirming prior associations with UC.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The variant rs149344982 was linked to prostate cancer, with its leading trait being alkaline phosphatase levels related to ALPL gene expression. This findings suggested that higher levels of ALP may indicate poor survival rates in prostate cancer patients, reflecting insights about the metabolic state associated with prostate cancer.
title: A scalable variational approach to characterize pleiotropic components across thousands of human diseases and complex traits using GWAS summary statistics

finding: A missense variant in the <italic>MARC1</italic> gene that was correlated with alkaline phosphatase levels.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: An intronic variant of <italic>EPHA2</italic> that correlates with γ-glutamyl transferase levels.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: This SNP was linked to mean corpuscular volume and located downstream of <italic>PTPRC</italic>.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: Fine-mapped for carpal tunnel syndrome and related to the gene <italic>THBS3</italic>.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: This SNP was identified as an AMD risk-raising variant associated with photoreceptor segment (PS) thinning. The study indicated a significant genome-wide association with PS thinning, highlighting its potential role as a predictive biomarker for future AMD.
title: Photoreceptor layer thinning is an early biomarker for age-related macular degeneration development: Epidemiological and genetic evidence from UK Biobank optical coherence tomography data

finding: This SNP showed a genome-wide significant association with PS thinning, reinforcing the connection between AMD risk-raising variants and reduced thickness in the photoreceptor layer.
title: Photoreceptor layer thinning is an early biomarker for age-related macular degeneration development: Epidemiological and genetic evidence from UK Biobank optical coherence tomography data

finding: This SNP demonstrated a substantial association with both PS thinning and RPE+BM thinning, positioning it as a critical variant in understanding AMD.
title: Photoreceptor layer thinning is an early biomarker for age-related macular degeneration development: Epidemiological and genetic evidence from UK Biobank optical coherence tomography data

finding: The GBA E365K variant (rs2230288) was confirmed as a significant risk factor for dementia progression in PD, with an HR of 2.33 and a p-value of 1.64 x 10^-04, further supporting existing literature regarding the impact of GBA mutations on cognitive decline.
title: Association between the LRP1B and APOE loci and the development of Parkinson’s disease dementia

finding: The SNP rs952593 was linked to gestational age in mothers with a beta of -1.66 and a p-value of 3.12x10^-7, suggesting its involvement in pregnancy duration and possibly related to preeclampsia risk.
title: Clotting factor genes are associated with preeclampsia in high altitude pregnant women in the Peruvian Andes

finding: The Duffy-null genotype (rs2814778; C/C homozygote) was associated with decreased absolute neutrophil count (ANC) in clozapine users, specifically in those of African, Asian, and Middle Eastern ancestries. This finding indicated that carriers of this genotype might be at greater risk of developing neutropenia when using clozapine.
title: Mediation and Longitudinal Analysis to interpret the association between clozapine pharmacokinetics, pharmacogenomics, and absolute neutrophil count

finding: This SNP was located in an enhancer within the CR1 gene body, a gene previously implicated in Alzheimer's disease, indicating its potential role in disease risk.
title: Cell-type specific cis-eQTLs in eight brain cell-types identifies novel risk genes for human brain disorders

finding: The SNP rs12061409 was associated with the utilization of colorectal cancer screening tests in various European countries. The research highlighted its relevance in optimizing colorectal cancer screening programs that rely on faecal immunochemical testing (FIT), particularly in the context of colonoscopy capacity constraints. This finding suggested that genetic factors could influence the effectiveness of screening strategies, ultimately impacting preventative measures and public health outcomes.
title: Colorectal cancer screening within colonoscopy capacity constraints: can FIT-based programmes save more lives by trading-off more sensitive test cut-offs against longer screening intervals?

finding: The SNP rs11207978 had a strong effect on liver ANGPTL3 expression, associated with reduced plasma triglyceride levels. It exhibited a modest effect on LDL cholesterol and a weaker effect on apoB levels. However, it was not linked to coronary artery disease (CAD) or other cardiometabolic diseases, suggesting its impact was primarily on lipid levels rather than disease risk.
title: Genetic inhibition of angiopoietin-like protein-3, lipoprotein-lipid levels and cardiometabolic diseases

finding: The SNP rs10889352 significantly influenced plasma ANGPTL3 levels, showing a very strong effect on plasma triglyceride levels, a modest effect on LDL cholesterol, and a weaker effect on apoB levels. Similar to rs11207978, it was not associated with CAD and other cardiometabolic diseases, underscoring its role in modulating lipoprotein-lipid levels rather than directly affecting disease outcomes.
title: Genetic inhibition of angiopoietin-like protein-3, lipoprotein-lipid levels and cardiometabolic diseases

finding: was noted near GIPC2, linked to Crohn's disease and lung cancer, denoting its significance in inflammatory pathways.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was linked as a lead SNP for HDL cholesterol and implicated in cardiometabolic conditions affecting cancer risk.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: was mentioned for its connection to DSTYK, involved in skin cancer risk.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: This variant was linked to Fc Fragment Of IgG Receptor IIIa (FCGR3A) in European ancestry, with its associated variants explaining up to 58% of the protein's variation.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: Found associated with FCGR3A in European ancestry, contributing to the overall finding of significant genetic influence on plasma proteome.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: This SNP was identified as a significant variant affecting FCGR3A protein levels in European ancestry.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: Linked with FCGR3A, this SNP was part of a set of variants explaining a large proportion of variation in protein expression.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: This variant contributed to the association with FCGR3A, being among those found to explain significant variance in protein levels in European ancestry.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: Linked with PLA2G12B, this variant was identified as a common causal factor in linkage with heart failure.
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: The CAMTA1 rs2412208 polymorphism emerged as independently related to survival in the Cox multivariable analysis, suggesting its significant contribution as a genetic modifier in the course of ALS.
title: The additive effect of genetic modifiers on ALS prognosis: a population-based study

finding: Located upstream of GORAB, this SNP (OR = 0.92, p = 1.87 × 10^-8) indicated a regulatory function associated with gene expression modulation.
title: A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies in 614,243 individuals identifies 59 novel susceptibility loci underlying Dupuytren’s contracture

finding: This SNP was in moderate LD with a previously identified lead SNP at the DDR2 gene locus, supporting its role in fibrosis.
title: A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies in 614,243 individuals identifies 59 novel susceptibility loci underlying Dupuytren’s contracture

finding: Observing similar genetic associations, this SNP indicated a link to the DDR2 gene, reaffirming its relevance to DD.
title: A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies in 614,243 individuals identifies 59 novel susceptibility loci underlying Dupuytren’s contracture

finding: SNP rs113665082 was part of a set that demonstrated approximately seven times higher odds for having IBS-U, indicating a significant association.
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: Similar to rs113665082, SNP rs111429581 also displayed significant association with IBS-U, reinforcing the findings for this locus.
title: Genetic Variants in Carbohydrate Digestive Enzyme and Transport Genes Associated with Risk of Irritable Bowel Syndrome

finding: This SNP was connected to RA and COVID-19 hospitalization in the MANEAL gene, reflecting its involvement in the shared genetic architecture.
title: Disentangling the common genetic architecture and causality of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus with COVID-19 outcomes: genome-wide cross trait analysis and bi-directional Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs3115534, located in intron 8 of the GBA1 gene, was identified as a novel common risk factor for Parkinson's disease (PD) in a study comprising predominantly African ancestry individuals. The odds ratio of 1.58 indicated that each copy of the G allele increased the risk of PD, and it also influenced age at onset, with a regression coefficient of -2.004 indicating an earlier onset for each risk allele. This allele was significantly more prevalent in African populations compared to other ancestries, confirming a unique genetic risk factor in this demographic.
title: Genome-wide Association Identifies Novel Etiological Insights Associated with Parkinson’s Disease in African and African Admixed Populations

finding: The missense SNV rs111033333 on USH2A was identified as a novel suggestive-level association through the AD-age score linear regression and replicated nominally, pointing to its possible link to AD.
title: A novel age-informed approach for genetic association analysis in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The rs1491377616 eQTL was identified as the most significant interaction with local skin inflammation, demonstrating an interaction beta of -3.86 (FDR = 1.59e-79). This SNP was in perfect LD with the psoriasis risk allele rs4845453 and associated with the expression of the gene LCE3C, which has been widely linked to psoriasis susceptibility due to its role in inflammatory skin responses.
title: Immunosuppression causes dynamic changes in expression QTLs in psoriatic skin

finding: The rs4072037:C>T variant in the MUC1 gene was associated with an increased risk of reported SARS-CoV-2 infection, influencing splice site selection and intron levels, thereby suggesting a pathway through which MUC1 splicing affects susceptibility.
title: Alternative splicing in the lung influences COVID-19 severity and respiratory diseases

finding: The SNP rs144126567 was reported as having a statistically significant positive causal effect on asthma as indicated by the strong association found in Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis. This finding underscored a genetic variant's influence on the M6n plasma glycan trait, suggesting a direct impact on the disease phenotype.
title: A genome-wide association study in 10,000 individuals links plasma N-glycome to liver disease and anti-inflammatory proteins

finding: The SNP rs1801133, a pathogenic variant at MTHFR, was found in patients of family F9 who were clinically diagnosed with Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome (BHDS). It was noted that these patients exhibited a positive family history of pulmonary cysts, suggesting a potential misdiagnosis related to Homocystinuria.
title: Genetic Insight into Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome in Indian patients reveals novel mutations in FLCN

finding: The SNP rs138189536, also pathogenic in MTHFR and detected in family F9, contributed to misdiagnosis of BHDS while potentially linking to Homocystinuria due to the patients' pulmonary cysts history.
title: Genetic Insight into Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome in Indian patients reveals novel mutations in FLCN

finding: The lead sQTL rs2245425 for TOR1AIP1 exhibited binary effects on sQTLs related to splicing events, indicating its significance in splicing regulation rather than transcription levels.
title: Integrative multi-ancestry genetic analysis of gene regulation in coronary arteries prioritizes disease risk loci

finding: The genetic variant rs410895 in CFHR2 was associated (P = 8.19 x 10<sup>22</sup>) with PRC thickness and had prior links to age-related macular degeneration (AMD), characterized by PRC atrophy.
title: Sub-cellular level resolution of common genetic variation in the photoreceptor layer identifies continuum between rare disease and common variation

finding: The SNP rs12092401 was linked to breast invasive carcinoma, kidney cancer, and low grade glioma in the Multi-Omic Graph Diagnosis (MOGDx) study. It demonstrated relevance as a multi-omic marker in identifying appropriate classifications for these heterogeneous diseases.
title: Multi-Omic Graph Diagnosis (MOGDx) : A data integration tool to perform classification tasks for heterogeneous diseases

finding: The SNP rs6025 represented the thrombophilic mutation F5 p.Arg534Gln (factor V Leiden), which reinforced a pathophysiologic role for venous thromboembolism, known as a secondary etiology of varicose veins as classified within the CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) framework.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome-wide Association Study of Varicose Veins Reveals Polygenic Architecture, Genetic Overlap with Arterial and Venous Disease, and Novel Therapeutic Opportunities

finding: The newly identified risk locus rs55750792 was located near the gene MFAP2 (microfibrillar associated protein 2) and was associated with increased circulating levels of MFAP2, which in turn linked to a higher risk of developing varicose veins.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome-wide Association Study of Varicose Veins Reveals Polygenic Architecture, Genetic Overlap with Arterial and Venous Disease, and Novel Therapeutic Opportunities

finding: The SNP rs12123737 was identified at the TGFBR3 locus, with genetically proxied circulating levels of TGFBI associated with an increased risk of varicose veins, corroborating prior findings of elevated TGFBI levels in affected individuals.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome-wide Association Study of Varicose Veins Reveals Polygenic Architecture, Genetic Overlap with Arterial and Venous Disease, and Novel Therapeutic Opportunities

finding: Finally, rs7530770 was significant (p=8.1E-03) in relation to tuberculosis, confirming its previously reported association in genetic studies.
title: Large Registry Based Analysis of Genetic Predisposition to Tuberculosis Identifies Genetic Risk Factors at HLA

finding: The SNP rs6587520 was associated with significant differences in lymphocyte counts specifically in European (EUR) populations, showing a per-allele effect size of -0.023, while no significant association was found in East Asian (EAS) populations (P = 0.52). This highlighted an ancestry-specific effect where the variant appeared to increase lymphocyte counts in EUR populations. The results suggested that variations in MCL1 expression levels across ancestries could influence the SNP's effect size on lymphocyte counts, indicating the relevance of gene-by-environment interactions in understanding ancestry-specific disease trends.
title: Ancestry-specific regulatory and disease architectures are likely due to cell-type-specific gene-by-environment interactions

finding: The 1298A/C (rs1801131) SNP showed a significant protective effect in breast cancer patients, specifically when the homozygous C genotype was present, indicating both recessive and homozygous co-dominant models demonstrated strong protective odds ratios.
title: Independent and Combined Associations of 677C/T and 1298A/C Polymorphisms in the MTHFR gene with Breast Cancers in a South-Asian Population

finding: The SNP rs1776354 was identified as a cis-eQTL in Natural Killer Cells for TNFRSF9, indicating its role in immune cell signaling.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: The SNP rs12740374, located in LD block 96, exhibited strong co-localization evidence influencing both eGFR-VTE and CAD, with a posterior probability (PP) greater than 0.7. This finding highlighted its potential role in the shared genetic architecture between these traits.
title: Disentangling shared genetic etiologies for kidney function and cardiovascular diseases

finding: SNP rs660240, located in the CELSR2 gene at the 1p13.3 locus, demonstrated strong co-localization for both eGFR and HF, as well as eGFR and VTE, with PP values exceeding 0.7. This provided robust evidence for its involvement in the biological pathways linking these traits.
title: Disentangling shared genetic etiologies for kidney function and cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs12071835 was associated with the HLA evolutionary divergence (HED) metric, which reflected the breadth of the immunopeptidome presented to host T cells.
