In the context of CAR T-cell therapy for relapsed/refractory large B-cell lymphoma (rrLBCL), the DQ1/DQ1 genotype linked to this SNP appeared as an independent predictor of durable response and was associated with a lower incidence of relapse/progression. The finding underscored the unexpected role of germline HLA-DQ molecules in influencing the host immune response after CAR T therapy.
title: Germline HLA-DQ genotype influences response to CAR T-cell therapy in patients with large B-cell lymphoma

finding: The analysis identified a variant in the TMC01 locus, specifically rs4656461, which was associated with a 12% increase in cumulative primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) incidence in a subgroup of participants. This finding highlighted that while the polygenic risk score (PRS) could measure a broader component of genetic burden, the specific SNP contributed to understanding the genetic risk related to glaucoma.
title: Polygenic Risk Score Improves Prediction of Primary Open Angle Glaucoma Onset in the Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study

finding: The rs3115534 variant at the GBA1 locus was identified as a top signal for Parkinson's disease in the African/African Admixed ancestry, suggesting a specialized genetic contribution to the disease in this population.
title: Multi-ancestry population attributable risk assessment of common genetic variation in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases

finding: The lead variant in the locus associated with NHW FEV1 NetSHy2 was identified as rs360060. It was shown to act as an eQTL for several genes, including TMEM63A, LEFTY1, and EPHX1, suggesting its potential impact on the gene expression related to lung function and COPD.
title: Proteomic Networks and Related Genetic Variants Associated with Smoking and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

finding: This SNP displayed a significant beta value in the analysis correlating zinc genetic variations to the risk of congenital foot deformities, reinforcing the established critical role of zinc in fetal development.
title: The Mendelian randomization analysis of trace elements Zinc, Selenium, Copper, Iron, and Phosphate with congenital foot deformities

finding: The SNP rs2769264 also showed a significant effect linking zinc exposure to congenital foot deformities, validating the findings on zinc's role during fetal development.
title: The Mendelian randomization analysis of trace elements Zinc, Selenium, Copper, Iron, and Phosphate with congenital foot deformities

finding: In locus 1p13.2, rs6537747 impacted both chronotype and retinal thickness, forging a connection between sleep and ocular health.
title: The role of sleep in the human brain and body: insights from multi-organ imaging genetics

finding: The rs2986758 SNP was identified as an eQTL variant that associated with both ESPN and TNFRSF25 genes. This association was linked to the audiometric patterns of patients with age-related hearing loss (ARHL), highlighting its relevance in the context of hearing impairment.
title: DNA Methylation Study in Presbycusis Patients

finding: The C-allele of the IL6R SNP (rs2228145 A>C) in donor kidneys was associated with a reduced risk of rejection after renal transplantation. Specifically, for each copy of the C-allele, the hazard ratio was 0.78 (95%-CI 0.67–0.90; P=0.001). Kaplan-Meier survival analyses substantiated this finding, showing that the incidence of biopsy-proven rejection decreased as the number of C-alleles increased.
title: Donor genetic variants in interleukin-6 and interleukin-6 receptor associate with biopsy-proven rejection following kidney transplantation

finding: The variant rs1801133 was located in the fifth exon of the MTHFR gene and was identified as significantly associated with early-onset schizophrenia (EOS) in a large-scale meta-analysis which included 2,159 EOS patients and 6,561 healthy controls (HC). This association underscored the importance of the MTHFR gene in contributing to schizophrenia risk, particularly in early-onset cases.
title: Early-onset schizophrenia is associated with immune-related rare variants in a Chinese sample

finding: The SNP rs2476601 from the PTPN22 locus on chromosome 1 was significantly associated with 9 types of autoantibody specificities, including Cit-Vim60-75 and Cit-Fibβ36-52. The association was stronger in HLA-DRB1 SE positive cases, indicating its role as a major risk factor for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and suggesting a pleiotropic effect related to multiple autoantibody phenotypes.
title: Identification of loci genetically associated with antibodies to specific sets of citrullinated peptides in rheumatoid arthritis patients

finding: The SNP rs6679677, in full linkage disequilibrium with rs2476601, was also associated with several autoantibody specificities in the context of RA, reinforcing the identified associations of the PTPN22 locus in this disease marker evaluation.
title: Identification of loci genetically associated with antibodies to specific sets of citrullinated peptides in rheumatoid arthritis patients

finding: This SNP, also in association with multiple autoantibody specificities, was identified as significantly associated particularly within the context of HLA-DRB1 SE positive individuals, mirroring findings with rs2476601.
title: Identification of loci genetically associated with antibodies to specific sets of citrullinated peptides in rheumatoid arthritis patients

finding: The missense SNP rs2228145 was previously reported to affect IL6R ectodomain shedding by ADAM10/17 metalloproteinases due to its alteration of cleavage sites, which was confirmed in the context of the study.
title: Genetic determinants of blood gene expression and splicing and their contribution to molecular phenotypes and health outcomes

finding: This SNP tagged the missense variant rs2228145 and was shown to influence a transmembrane splicing event of IL6R, mediating a 4.67% effect on plasma protein abundance.
title: Genetic determinants of blood gene expression and splicing and their contribution to molecular phenotypes and health outcomes

finding: This SNP represented a missense mutation (Asp358Ala) in the IL6R gene. It was associated with the protein's shift from a membrane-bound state to a soluble fraction and was implicated in increased AD risk and decreased rheumatoid arthritis risk.
title: Triangulating molecular evidence to prioritise candidate causal genes at established atopic dermatitis loci

finding: The SNP rs6127 (c.1807G>A; p.Asp603Asn) was identified as a significant genetic factor associated with COVID-19 severity, particularly in male subjects. The homozygosity for the Asn allele (Asn/Asn) showed an odds ratio (OR) of 2.27, indicating over twofold increased risk for severe outcomes related to thromboembolism. This association was further strengthened in males older than 50 years, where the OR was 2.42. The findings emphasized the role of the SELP gene in enhancing platelet activation and leukocyte recruitment, which are critical in the pathological response to COVID-19.
title: SELP Asp603Asn and severe thrombosis in COVID-19 males: implication for anti P-selectin monoclonal antibodies treatment

finding: The study identified rs1337526 as a lead SNP associated with the urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) in a genome-wide association study (GWAS) conducted on participants from the UK Biobank. Fine-mapping of the FOXD2 locus confirmed this association, suggesting that rs1337526 likely contributes to the regulation of albuminuria, thereby indicating its essential role in kidney function.
title: Implication of FOXD2 dysfunction in syndromic congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT)

finding: Fine-mapping efforts revealed rs17453832 as another significant SNP upstream of FOXD2, associated with albuminuria. This SNP was shown to overlap accessible chromatin regions specifically in podocytes, which are critical for the glomerular filtration function leading to albuminuria. Hence, rs17453832 was characterized as a regulatory variant of FOXD2, highlighting its importance in the context of kidney-related phenotypes.
title: Implication of FOXD2 dysfunction in syndromic congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT)

finding: The screening for the MTHFR1 gene (rs1801133) identified that around 26% of patients admitted with a risk of developing thrombophilia carried at least one allele of the MTHFR1 mutation. The breakdown showed 24% of patients were heterozygote, with 2% being homozygote recessive.
title: KASP-PCR method to screen thrombophilia genetic risk factors

finding: In the case of the MTHFR2 gene (rs1801131), it was found that approximately 45% of susceptible thrombophilia patients carried at least one mutation. This comprised 39% heterozygotes and 6.3% homozygote recessive, with 53% being free of mutation.
title: KASP-PCR method to screen thrombophilia genetic risk factors

finding: In the multi-trait analysis, the variant rs4844610 in the CR1 gene was associated with delirium, presenting an Odds Ratio of 1.01 and a p-value of 1.4×10^-8, supporting its relevance in the context of Alzheimer's disease and delirium.
title: Dissecting the genetic and proteomic risk factors for delirium

finding: The frequency of the minor G allele for rs1800947 was significantly higher in the preterm labour (PTL) group compared to control, suggesting an association with PTL risk. This was the first time such a finding had been reported, indicating that mutations in rs1800947 could lead to PTL.
title: Association of C-reactive protein and Interleukin-6 single nucleotide polymorphisms with preterm labour: results of a pilot study

finding: The SNP rs1415287 colocalized with the T2D risk allele associated with increased levels of CBLN4 and decreased levels of IGFBP-1. This colocalization was robust, as it was identified in both deCODE and UKB pQTL datasets, and highlighted the relationships between these metabolites and T2D risk.
title: Multi-omics characterization of type 2 diabetes associated genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs11240388 was identified as part of a newly significant locus on Chr1 associated with Covid-19 hospitalization. It was observed to be located within a 79Kb haplotype encompassing the DSTYK gene, suggesting a potential role in modulating immune response to Covid-19. The analysis revealed that despite an increased frequency of the risk allele (G) among individuals with high African ancestry, significant association with Covid-19 severity was confined to those with high European ancestry.
title: Genetic risk factors and Covid-19 severity in Brazil: results from BRACOVID Study

finding: The SNP rs146953046 in the PHGDH gene located at locus 1p12 was reported as a significant risk factor for MacTel, showing an odds ratio of 5.47. This rare SNP was associated with lower expression of PHGDH in retinal tissues, suggesting its involvement in serine biosynthesis and contributing to retinal degeneration.
title: Identification of genetic factors influencing metabolic dysregulation and retinal support for MacTel, a retinal disorder

finding: SNP rs532303, associated with the PHGDH locus in the present analysis showed significant findings (P=2.3×10-20) and was in strong linkage disequilibrium with the previously identified risk SNP, indicating its potential importance in MacTel susceptibility.
title: Identification of genetic factors influencing metabolic dysregulation and retinal support for MacTel, a retinal disorder

finding: The SNP rs20558 was found to be the lead isoQTL for the isoform ENST00000466964.1 of the LAMC1 gene. It was significantly associated with colorectal cancer risk (CRC), displaying a strong colocalization with GWAS signals and a posterior inclusion probability of 1. However, it showed no effect on BABAM1 gene expression.
title: Isoform-level analyses of 6 cancers uncover extensive genetic risk mechanisms undetected at the gene-level

finding: The variant rs11576941 was associated with eosinophil count on the fatty acid amide hydrolase gene (FAAH). FAAH is involved in endocannabinoid metabolism and had previously been identified as a candidate gene for cannabis use and dependence, specifically in the Mexican American population under study. This variant contributed to understanding the genetic basis of cannabis use disorder (CUD) severity and its relationship to endocannabinoid system functions.
title: Pleiotropic Loci for Cannabis Use Disorder Severity in Multi-Ancestry High-Risk Populations

finding: The SNP rs7522520 was independently identified near the pseudogene RN7SK, with a significant association with misophonia at a p-value of 3.57 × 10^-8. This SNP was part of a linkage disequilibrium block that collated traits related to wellbeing.
title: Genetic evidence for the link of misophonia with psychiatric disorders and personality

finding: The SNP rs4430311 was associated with an increased risk of schizophrenia through the isoform ENST00000492957 of AKT3. This association exhibited a significant negative relationship, where increasing SCZ risk alleles correlated with decreased expression, even though the SNP only exhibited a nominal positive association with the overall gene expression of AKT3. The implications of this finding suggest a complex interaction of AKT3 isoforms in relation to brain traits.
title: Isoform-level transcriptome-wide association uncovers extensive novel genetic risk mechanisms for neuropsychiatric disorders in the human brain

finding: The rs113403872 variant in the PKLR gene was associated with both plasma pyruvate level and red blood cell count, confirming the established link between PKLR mutations and haemolytic anaemia.
title: Mendelian randomisation with proxy exposures: challenges and opportunities

finding: Similar to rs113403872, the rs116100695 variant in the PKLR gene was significantly associated with plasma pyruvate levels and red blood cell count, reinforcing the relationship with haemolytic anaemia.
title: Mendelian randomisation with proxy exposures: challenges and opportunities

finding: The SNP rs61804494 also demonstrated significant interaction with fish oil supplementation and presented an interaction pattern that contrasted with that of APOE ε4. This underscored the complexity of genetic influences on dementia outcomes related to dietary factors.
title: Gene-diet interaction analysis in UK Biobank identified genetic loci that modify the association between fish oil supplementation and the incidence of dementia

finding: Similar to rs7528419, rs629301, also located in the SORT1 locus, was found to be associated with coronary heart disease (CHD) in GWAS. PRISM attributed a vertical effect on CHD and a direct effect on apoB, affirming the role of apoB in mediating the risk of CHD.
title: Inferring genetic variant causal network by leveraging pleiotropy

finding: The SNP rs646776, residing in the SORT1 locus, showed a strong association with coronary heart disease (CHD) per GWAS findings. According to PRISM, it exhibited a vertical effect on CHD influenced directly through apoB, suggesting that the influence on CHD is mediated specifically by the effects on apoB levels.
title: Inferring genetic variant causal network by leveraging pleiotropy

finding: The SNP rs75437404 located near the loricrin gene (LOR) on chromosome 1 was associated with increased susceptibility to astrovirus diarrhea in children within the first year of life. The meta-analysis revealed a p-value of 8.82×10^-9 and an odds ratio (OR) of 2.71 for carriers of the A allele compared to those with the T allele.
title: Genetic Susceptibility to Astrovirus Diarrhea in Bangladeshi Infants

finding: The SNP rs12125683 was previously identified as being associated with the expression of several innate immune response genes including PGLYRP4, S100A9, and S100A12. The C allele was associated with a higher expression of these genes in different tissues and an odds ratio of 2.23 was observed in connection with these expression levels.
title: Genetic Susceptibility to Astrovirus Diarrhea in Bangladeshi Infants

finding: The SNP rs17020312 was identified with the meQTL for IKBKE in naive CD4+ T cells from lupus patients, indicating its significance in immune signaling pathways associated with the disease.
title: Hypomethylation of miR-17-92 cluster in lupus T cells and no significant role for genetic factors in the lupus-associated DNA methylation signature

finding: The SNP rs67652997 was identified in the context of the IRF6 locus and noted for being significant for the cleft lip plus (CL[P]) subtype; this position coincided with the highest significance for associated SNPs in that category.
title: Genome-wide association study of multiethnic non-syndromic orofacial cleft families identifies novel loci specific to family and phenotypic subtypes

finding: The SNP rs2076149 was associated with the cleft lip plus subtype and also demonstrated strong significance within the cleft lip plus-cleft palate categories, representing a significant positive original finding.
title: Genome-wide association study of multiethnic non-syndromic orofacial cleft families identifies novel loci specific to family and phenotypic subtypes

finding: The rs1690789 SNP was associated with an active enhancer element that increased the expression of the TGFB2 gene in human lung fibroblasts. This finding is significant as it demonstrates a direct link between the genetic variant identified by genome-wide association analysis (GWAS) of emphysema and the TGF-β signaling pathway, which is dysregulated in emphysema. It provided evidence supporting the role of the TGF-β pathway in emphysema pathology.
title: Lung transcriptomics of radiologic emphysema reveal barrier function impairment and macrophage M1-M2 imbalance

finding: The SNP rs2072659 was associated with multiple smoking phenotypes in a protective direction. Specifically, it was linked to 'cig-per-day' (Beta=-0.04; CI=-0.02--0.05; P=7.5e-8), 'heavy-smoker' (OR=0.96; CI=0.94-0.98; P=5.3e-6), 'ever-smoker' (OR=0.98; CI=0.97-0.99; P=0.001), and 'nicotine-dependence' (OR=0.97; CI=0.95-0.99; P=0.003). This SNP's protective association indicated a potential convergence between common and rare variant effects on smoking behaviors.
title: Rare coding variants in CHRNB2 reduce the likelihood of smoking

finding: The missense variant rs202079239 (Arg460Gly) in <CHRNB2> was identified as the most significant contributor in burden analyses regarding smoking phenotypes. It demonstrated a protective association with heavy smoking (OR=0.58; CI=0.45-0.74; P=2e-5) and exhibited higher frequency in the Finnish population compared to non-Finnish Europeans. Its analysis in the FinnGen cohort revealed protective associations with substance use disorder (OR=0.39; CI=0.21-0.73; P=0.003) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (OR=0.69; CI=0.49-0.96; P=0.03).
title: Rare coding variants in CHRNB2 reduce the likelihood of smoking

finding: The genetic variant rs10917151 in CDC42/WNT4 was associated with an ancestry-specific effect on the risk of uterine fibroids. Specifically, the A allele was linked to a reduced risk in women of African ancestry (OR=0.84) and an increased risk in women of European ancestry (OR=1.16). This SNP had been implicated in hormone-related traits and was suggested to influence hormone metabolism related to the development of leiomyomas.
title: Exploring potential causal genes for uterine leiomyomas: A summary data-based Mendelian randomization and FUMA analysis

finding: The SNP rs2340405 showed significant associations with both alcohol use disorder (AUD) and schizophrenia (SCZ). Specifically, it had a cross-disorder p-value of 2.4e-17, with individual p-values of 5.8e-8 for AUD and 2.2e-13 for SCZ. It was also linked to other psychiatric disorders, including major depression, although not genome-wide significant.
title: Evidence of shared genetic influences underlying schizophrenia and alcohol use disorder, but not alcohol consumption

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with at least one trait out of 706 examined traits in UK Biobank using TraitScan. The traits that had a strong association suggested potential links to the rare bone tumor Ewing Sarcoma (EWS), indicating its relevance in the pathology of this cancer.
title: Subset scanning for multi-trait analysis using GWAS summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs11240569 was examined in a case-control study for its polymorphism in relation to Parkinson's disease, particularly focusing on cognitive impairment in a population in Upper Egypt. The study highlighted a significant association of this SNP with Parkinson's disease and its cognitive aspects, suggesting its potential role in the disease's manifestation.
title: The State of Play of Parkinson’s Disease in Africa: A Systematic Review and Point of View

finding: The rs6677604 allele A was found to tag for a deletion at the CFHR3–1 locus. It was established that patients with this allele also had homozygous deletions of CFHR1. This SNP was associated with altered expression levels of multiple proteins involved in immune response regulation, further confirming its variant significance in the context of kidney transplant rejection risk.
title: The impact of complement factor H-related protein gene deletions on kidney transplantation

finding: In macrophages, the most significant eQTL was observed for rs140584594, showing a positive association between expression of Glutathione S-Transferase Mu 1 (GSTM1) and the allele A.
title: History of tuberculosis disease is associated with genetic regulatory variation in Peruvians

finding: The rs366316 SNP was strongly associated with CD1A expression in dendritic cells, yet this association did not correlate with TB history, marking a notable gene regulation pathway.
title: History of tuberculosis disease is associated with genetic regulatory variation in Peruvians

finding: The missense variant rs848208 in SPEN was associated with atrial fibrillation, indicating its biological relevance given the implications of SPEN in heart development and conduction.
title: Trans-ancestry genome-wide analysis of atrial fibrillation provides new insights into disease biology and enables polygenic prediction of cardioembolic risk

finding: An intronic variant in NEGR1, this finding was novel for AUDIT-C. NEGR1 had prior associations with intelligence and educational attainment, suggesting influences on this trait.
title: Genetic underpinnings of the transition from alcohol consumption to alcohol use disorder: shared and unique genetic architectures in a cross-ancestry sample

finding: Identified as having the strongest direct effect on AUD, this variant in LINC01360 highlighted its impact on alcohol use biology.
title: Genetic underpinnings of the transition from alcohol consumption to alcohol use disorder: shared and unique genetic architectures in a cross-ancestry sample

finding: The SNP rs12040800 was identified as part of a nine-gene signature utilized to predict the response to preoperative chemoradiotherapy in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC). This discovery was significant as it provided a potential biomarker for identifying patients who could specifically benefit from the neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy treatment.
title: Exploring novel inflammation-related genetic and hematological predictors of response to neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy in locally advanced rectal cancer

finding: The SNP rs2282440 was positively associated with metabolic syndrome in a study conducted on the Taiwanese population. This finding suggested that variations in the Syndecan-3 gene may play a role in the development of metabolic syndrome, which is characterized by a cluster of conditions including obesity, insulin resistance, and cardiovascular risk factors.
title: Plasma proteomic signatures of adiposity are associated with cardiovascular risk factors and type 2 diabetes risk in a multi-ethnic Asian population

finding: The rs1479489847 variant within the SRRM1 gene exhibited a strong association with the hospitalization phenotype, with an odds ratio of 4.17, suggesting significant impact on disease manifestation.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: The rs911647797 variant in the IL6R gene showed a remarkable association with hospitalization, presenting an odds ratio of 6.19, underscoring its importance in the context of COVID-19 treatment strategies.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: The variant rs11591147 was identified as a missense mutation in the PCSK9 gene, which had a strong effect on LDL cholesterol levels, indicated by a beta coefficient of 0.50 (95% CI [0.46, 0.53], p = 9 × 10^-143) in the Global Lipids Genetics Consortium (GLGC) analysis. Additionally, this SNP was associated with coronary artery disease (CAD), with an allelic beta of 0.50 (95% CI [0.46, 0.53], p = 9 × 10^-143), and demonstrated an odds ratio of 1.29 (95% CI [1.16, 1.45], p = 7 × 10^-6) in the CARDIoGRAMplusC4D consortium, thus underlining its significant role in both LDL-c levels and CAD.
title: ExPheWas: a browser for gene-based pheWAS associations

finding: The rs4745 variant (p.D159V) in the EFNA1 gene was associated with duodenal ulcer (DU) and had a posterior inclusion probability (PIP) of 0.05. This variant was common in both East Asian and European populations and was the lead variant for cis-splicing quantitative trait loci (sQTL) affecting EFNA1 expression in the stomach.
title: East Asian-specific and cross-ancestry genome-wide meta-analyses provide mechanistic insights into peptic ulcer disease

finding: The rs4390169 variant, located upstream of EFNA1, had a PIP of 0.06 for DU and was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs4745 (r2 = 0.99 in 1KG EAS and EUR). It was identified as the lead variant for cis-protein QTL (pQTL) impacting EFNA1 levels in plasma.
title: East Asian-specific and cross-ancestry genome-wide meta-analyses provide mechanistic insights into peptic ulcer disease

finding: The SNP rs2814778 was associated with Duffy receptor status in Black individuals. Specifically, the CC genotype indicated Duffy null status, which was expected to influence levels of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP). However, the study found that Duffy null status was not independently associated with elevated hs-CRP levels nor higher incidence of all-cause mortality or adverse cardiovascular outcomes after adjusting for confounding factors.
title: The Relationship of Duffy Gene Polymorphism, High Sensitivity C-Reactive Protein, and Long-term Outcomes

finding: The rs372257803 variant in ANGPTL3 demonstrated protective effects against hyperlipidaemia, noted for lowering non-HDL cholesterol and triglycerides, signified by an odds ratio of 0.59.
title: Weighted burden analysis of rare coding variants in 470,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subject characterises effects on hyperlipidaemia risk

finding: The SNP rs2993439, which is located upstream of the LGR6 gene on Chromosome 1, showed a trend of genome-wide significant association with total niacin flushing scores in patients with schizophrenia (p = 8.32E-08, β = 3.066). This finding indicated a potential causal role of niacin response in the etiology of schizophrenia.
title: Causal associations between niacin bluntness and schizophrenia: a GWAS and Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs3010092, found in the intron of the LRG6 gene, also displayed a trend of genome-wide significant association with total niacin flushing scores in schizophrenia patients (p = 8.32E-08, β = 3.066). This association further supported the role of niacin response alterations in contributing to schizophrenia.
title: Causal associations between niacin bluntness and schizophrenia: a GWAS and Mendelian randomization study

finding: The IL-10 -592 C>A polymorphism demonstrated an association with prostate cancer in the Caucasian population, showing a significant odds ratio of 1.08 with a 95% CI of 1.01-1.16 utilizing the allele contrast model.
title: Interleukin- 10 (IL-10) gene polymorphisms and prostate cancer susceptibility: evidence from a meta-analysis

finding: The missense variant rs7522061-C in the FCRL3 locus was identified as a novel association with TPOAb levels, contributing to the understanding of immune responses in autoimmune thyroid diseases.
title: Genome-wide association studies of thyroid-related hormones, dysfunction, and autoimmunity among 85,421 Chinese pregnancies

finding: The rs72660908 SNP was associated with Rhesus isoimmunization during pregnancy, demonstrating a recessive inheritance pattern linked to deletions in the RHD gene. The odds ratio (OR) for homozygotes was significantly high (OR=24.3), while it was not significant for heterozygotes (OR_Hetero=1.18). There was a notable linkage disequilibrium between this variant and a large deletion affecting the RHD gene.
title: Decoding Genetics, Ancestry, and Geospatial Context for Precision Health

finding: The rs6025 SNP (c.1601G>A, p.Arg534Gln) in the F5 gene was strongly associated with congenital deficiency of other clotting factors, particularly factor VII, showing a calculated odds ratio of 11.56. This high association underlined its clinical significance.
title: Decoding Genetics, Ancestry, and Geospatial Context for Precision Health

finding: This SNP (rs12061672) was identified as a relevant biomarker in the context of lung cancer screening, particularly related to the sensitivity and specificity of autoantibody testing for early detection of the disease. The findings indicated that the specificity for early stage lung cancer detection reached 90.3%, supporting the notion that autoantibodies could be crucial in selecting individuals at highest risk, thereby enhancing the effectiveness of targeted screening approaches.
title: Targeted screening for lung cancer with autoantibodies

finding: The SNP rs2235529 was linked to the WNT4 locus at 1p36.12, achieving a Bonferroni-corrected significance (P = 9.12x10-8), indicating its relevance in the analysis of endometriosis.
title: Enhancing Genetic Association Power in Endometriosis through Unsupervised Clustering of Clinical Subtypes Identified from Electronic Health Records

finding: The SNP rs655853 was associated with the DNM3 locus at 1q24.3 and reached significance with a Bonferroni-corrected p-value of 3.54x10-5, contributing to the understanding of genetic factors in endometriosis.
title: Enhancing Genetic Association Power in Endometriosis through Unsupervised Clustering of Clinical Subtypes Identified from Electronic Health Records

finding: The SNP rs7413471 was associated with PTSD as one of the loci identified through the study and had a high CADD score, underscoring its relevance to PTSD genetic risk.
title: The genetic relationships between post-traumatic stress disorder and its corresponding neural circuit structures

finding: The rs41264915 intronic variant in the THBS3 gene, which was associated with increased mucin-1 expression, was linked to critical COVID-19 outcomes in a genome-wide association study. This SNP appeared to influence the severity of COVID-19, highlighting a complex relationship between mucin-1 levels and COVID-19 pathology, where both increased and decreased mucin-1 production had different implications for disease risk and severity.
title: Eight-Fold Increased COVID-19 Mortality in Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease due to MUC1 Mutations: An Observational Study

finding: A positive association was found between the rs2282440 SNP of the Syndecan-3 gene and metabolic syndrome in the Taiwanese population, indicating its role in this complex metabolic disorder.
title: Variability in proteoglycan biosynthetic genes reveals new facets of heparan sulfates diversity. A systematic review and analysis

finding: The SNP rs3397 in TNFRSF1B was linked to Mycobacterium avium paratuberculosis infection and was also correlated with osteoporosis in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. This finding emphasized the role of genetic polymorphisms in susceptibility to MAP infection, which may have implications for understanding disease mechanisms in autoimmune conditions like Crohn's disease.
title: Presence Of Infection By Mycobacterium Avium Subsp. Paratuberculosis In The Blood Of Patients With Crohn’s Disease And Control Subjects Shown By Multiple Laboratory Culture And Antibody Methods

finding: The study reported a significant association between the FCGR2A H131R SNP (rs1801274) and primary immunodeficiencies (PID), specifically highlighting a difference between the PID cohort and controls (X2 = 7.884, p = 0.019). This SNP's variants influenced IgG binding affinity, with the H variant associated with higher affinity compared to the R variant.
title: FCGR2A-131H/H is under-represented amongst patients with primary immunodeficiencies

finding: In the context of the TNNI3K locus, rs1040070 demonstrated its involvement through interactions within NTERA2 cells, linking it to implications in metabolic regulation.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: This variant was also found to interact within the TNNI3K locus, implying connections between gene regulation and childhood obesity.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: The SNP rs11118288 on chromosome 1 was discovered to colocalize with a pulse rate locus, indicating its relevance to heart rate regulation and showcasing a connection between latent phenotypes and known cardiovascular traits.
title: Unsupervised cardiac MRI phenotyping with 3D diffusion autoencoders reveals novel genetic insights

finding: The SNP rs12141375:A was reported to explain 32.7% of the variance in plasma CHIT1 levels, showcasing its strong effect and cis-association signal. This finding related to a molecular phenotype demonstrated significant genetic architecture variation, emphasizing the role of individual genetic variants in influencing plasma protein levels.
title: Mapping genetic determinants of 184 circulating proteins in 26,494 individuals to connect proteins and diseases

finding: The SNP rs10889338 in DOCK7 was identified as associated with hypercholesterolemia using the CC-liability method and was significant in other GWAS studies within the UK Biobank.
title: Genetic association studies using disease liabilities from deep neural networks

finding: The SNP rs1674395504 was associated with the Skraban-Deardorff syndrome and was found to create an alternative splice acceptor site within the second intron of the WDR26 gene. In the context of the study, this variant was classified with conflicting interpretations of pathogenicity, as it was submitted as pathogenic, likely pathogenic, and a variant of uncertain significance (VUS) in ClinVar. An in-silico analysis indicated a deleterious effect on splicing with a SpliceAI delta score of 1, suggesting a significant impact on transcripts. The RNA sequencing data revealed that approximately 58% of junctions included this new acceptor site, indicating that nearly half of the transcripts were alternatively spliced, consistent with the heterozygous state of this SNP.
title: RNA sequencing uplifts diagnostic rate in undiagnosed rare disease patients

finding: The SNP rs10753232 in STX6 demonstrated a significant association with PSP, featuring a p-value of 6.79 × 10^-10, reaffirming previous findings in the context of the disease.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs6687758 was significantly associated with PSP, showing a p-value of 3.36 × 10^-6 and contributing to the understanding of the DUSP10 locus.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs12026659 was identified with significant association with a p-value of 9.48 × 10^-7 in the context of PSP, particularly related to DUSP10 genetic region.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs839764 was suggestively associated with PSP at p = 7.94 × 10^-7, providing insights into ELOVL1 and its potential impact on the disease.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: Research demonstrated that rs12030534 was pertinent to enhancing therapeutic strategies post-surgical resection of pancreatic cancers, aiding in treatment planning.
title: Graph Attention Networks for Drug Combination Discovery: Targeting Pancreatic Cancer Genes with RAIN Protocol

finding: The rs1800896 single gene polymorphism in IL-10 showed a direct link with COVID-19 susceptibility, indicating that this SNP was associated with increased risk of symptomatic COVID-19 infection.
title: COVID-19 and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: a common susceptibility pattern?

finding: The SNP rs1805407, located in the PARP1 gene, was linked to increased sensitivity to PARP1 inhibitors in cancer cells. This suggests that individuals carrying this variant may benefit from improved therapeutic strategies in cancer treatment.
title: Disentangling Predictors of COPD Mortality with Probabilistic Graphical Models

finding: This SNP was associated with arthrosis, exhibiting a strong link (P=2×10^-14), which signifies its relevance to joint diseases.
title: Leveraging large-scale multi-omics to identify therapeutic targets from genome-wide association studies

finding: This coding variant in IL6R was significantly associated with coronary atherosclerosis and abdominal aortic aneurysm, indicating its role in cardiovascular disease risk.
title: Leveraging large-scale multi-omics to identify therapeutic targets from genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs486907 was identified as having a sex-specific effect regarding susceptibility to melanoma skin cancer, with its interaction with miR-146a rs2910164 showing a significant role in this disease risk, particularly in relation to gender.
title: Systematic review reveals multiple sexually antagonistic polymorphisms affecting human disease and complex traits

finding: The SNP rs6691952 was associated with RBS-R restricted, showing a significant p-value of 6.9 × 10^-8. This SNP lies within an intron of the HHAT gene, which has previously been associated with schizophrenia.
title: Clinical autism subscales have common genetic liability that is heritable, pleiotropic, and generalizable to the general population

finding: The SNP rs6695837 was identified as a functional polymorphism located near the LAMC1 gene. This locus conferred risk of colorectal cancer in Chinese populations, suggesting its significant role in cancer predisposition.
title: Identification of Key Genes and Signaling Pathways Associated with the Progression of Glioblastoma multiform

finding: The SNP rs6025, a missense variant within the F5 gene, was identified from the ATLAS GWAS of venous thromboembolism in the European ancestry group. The analysis performed a PheWAS that included this SNP and discovered phenotypic associations with iatrogenic pulmonary embolism and infarction, as well as other venous embolism and thrombosis. These findings were consistent with the existing understanding of the pathophysiology associated with venous thromboembolism, demonstrating the effectiveness of PheWAS in linking genetic variants to clinical phenotypes.
title: The UCLA ATLAS Community Health Initiative: promoting precision health research in a diverse biobank

finding: It was identified as an eQTL in the first trimester (Tri1) for the gene WARS2 with a beta of -0.89 and an FDR of 3.88e-13, but did not show significant association in the second trimester (Tri2). This illustrates the differential regulatory environment in fetal brain development.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: This SNP served as an ieQTL for BRINP2 and showed significant colocalization with SCZ GWAS, implicating it in neuropsychiatric disease through regulation of brain development processes.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: The rs1801133 variant in the MTHFR gene was associated with the risk of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in the Chinese population. This finding was particularly relevant as the study examined food group consumption and its relationship with the development of NAFLD, linking genetic predisposition from the SNP to dietary habits.
title: Consumption of legumes and risk of hepatobiliary diseases among humans aged 2+ years: a scoping review

finding: The rs61817953 variant, situated near PIK3C2B, was associated with a decreased risk of HNSCC, with an odds ratio of 0.90 (95% CI: 0.87, 0.93, p_meta=2.17×10^-8). This finding contributed to identifying novel loci related to the disease.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The rs6679311 variant, located near MDM4, showed an increased risk of HNSCC with an odds ratio of 1.11 (95% CI: 1.07, 1.14, p_meta=1.25×10^-10). This marker served as a significant predictor of risk within the study.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The study found that the rs1146473 variant on chromosome 1 was associated with an odds ratio of 1.32 for spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD), with a significant P-value of 5.8 x 10^-9. This locus was novel for SCAD and any cardiovascular disease. The tissue factor gene (F3), which is crucial in blood coagulation, was identified as the nearest coding gene to this SNP. Importantly, the risk allele at rs1146473 colocalized with an eQTL signal for F3 in the aorta, suggesting that lower expression of F3 in arterial tissues might be a mechanism contributing to the risk of SCAD.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis of spontaneous coronary artery dissection reveals common variants and genes related to artery integrity and tissue-mediated coagulation

finding: The lead SNP rs6679677 was associated with pernicious anemia, highlighting a significant link to autoimmune processes due to its proximity to the PTPN22 gene, which is known for its role in various autoimmune diseases.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies five risk loci for pernicious anemia and implicates the role of HLA-DR15 haplotype

finding: NUCKS1 rs823118 was involved in significant predictive models influencing clinical features of PD, such as affecting levels of alpha-synuclein in CSF.
title: The multi-modality neuroimaging analysis identified an essential genetic variant associated with Parkinson’s disease

finding: At rs35749011, heterozygous and homozygous 'A' alleles were coded as '1', indicating a genetic association with an increased risk of Parkinson's disease through the GBA1 E326K variant.
title: Gut-Brain Nexus: Mapping Multi-Modal Links to Neurodegeneration at Biobank Scale

finding: For rs76763715, individuals with heterozygous and homozygous 'C' alleles were coded as '1', linking this SNP to genetic risk factors for Parkinson's disease through the GBA1 N370S variant.
title: Gut-Brain Nexus: Mapping Multi-Modal Links to Neurodegeneration at Biobank Scale

finding: The missense variant rs1801133 was implicated in reduced enzymatic activity and higher homocysteine levels, associated with conditions like colorectal cancer and Alzheimer’s disease. It was identified from enQTL-colocalized events in CD8 cells, targeting the gene KIAA2013.
title: Genetic determinants of gene expression noise and its role in complex trait variation

finding: SNP rs742510, an intronic variant in DNM3, was identified as novel and associated with AUD.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: The SNP rs7531118 was noted for having the most significant association with depression (P = 3.20 × 10^−31) in the extensive meta-analysis, being located approximately 89 kb downstream of the NEGR1 gene. This finding was significant as NEGR1 has been consistently implicated in depression, demonstrating a crucial role in neuronal growth and associated behaviors.
title: Cross-ancestry genome-wide association study and systems-level integrative analyses implicate new risk genes and therapeutic targets for depression

finding: The SNP rs12071819 was associated with melanoma risk and was found to have significant implications for sex and gender disparities in the disease. The original finding suggested that differences in survival rates based on gender were linked to this SNP, helping to explain the observed survival disparities in malignant melanoma patients in Hungary.
title: SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT IN MELANOMA SURVIVAL OVER THE LAST DECADE: A HUNGARIAN NATIONWIDE STUDY BETWEEN 2011–2019

finding: The SNP rs11583641 was previously noted in relation to COLGALT2 and its upregulation effect through decreased levels of DNA methylation. This study further supported that the associated SNP rs12023991, which is in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with it, led to an upregulation of COLGALT2 in lesioned cartilage.
title: Allelic expression imbalance in articular cartilage and subchondral bone refined genome-wide association signals in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs12023991 was linked to an upregulation effect on COLGALT2 with the risk allele leading to a meta-φ of 0.54, suggesting a co-regulation mechanism at play in the expression levels of this gene in OA.
title: Allelic expression imbalance in articular cartilage and subchondral bone refined genome-wide association signals in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs12123818 was associated with a mouse ovarian cancer and peritoneal metastasis model for studying intraperitoneal chemotherapy. This research suggested that the genetic variation could influence response to chemotherapy in the context of ovarian cancer.
title: Performance of different nebulizers in clinical use for Pressurized Intraperitoneal Aerosol Chemotherapy (PIPAC)

finding: Variant rs4379719 showed a significant effect when removed from the analysis, revealing a link between insomnia and increasing motor decline in PD. It was associated with napping, indicating a mechanism through which it may affect sleep and cognitive progression.
title: Relationship between sleep and progression of Parkinson’s disease – A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The study identified rs2229682 as part of a credible set of eSNPs in the SLC2A1 gene, which were associated with a burden of damaging missense variants. This association was relevant to major depressive disorder as defined by ICD10 code F32.9, contributing to the understanding of genetic factors influencing depression.
title: Whole exome sequencing in the UK Biobank reveals risk gene SLC2A1 and biological insights for major depressive disorder

finding: Similar to rs2229682, rs11537641 was found within a credible set of eSNPs related to SLC2A1 and the burden of damaging missense variants. The findings indicated that these variants have a significant association with major depressive disorder, further elucidating the genetic component of depression.
title: Whole exome sequencing in the UK Biobank reveals risk gene SLC2A1 and biological insights for major depressive disorder

finding: The rs1136410 variant, a missense variant in PARP1, was linked to a reduced risk of DNMT3A-CHIP, with an odds ratio of 0.88 and a very significant p-value.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: This variant in TIE1 significantly increased the risk of acquiring mCAaut phenotype, with an odds ratio of 8.5.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: This rare variant in PTPRF was also linked to increased risk of mCAaut, evidencing strong associations with an odds ratio of 16.47.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: The rs1801133 variant in the MTHFR gene was more commonly found in PD patients with 32-52% Native American ancestry compared to controls, demonstrating a statistically significant relationship with an OR of 2.02 and a p-value of 0.043. This SNP has been specifically reported only in the Mexican population, suggesting unique genetic factors affecting PD incidence in this demographic.
title: MEX-PD: A National Network for the Epidemiological & Genetic Research of Parkinson’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs12092716 was identified as a positive and original finding in the context of radiation-induced hypothyroidism (RIHT) among patients who underwent intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) for head and neck cancers. This SNP was included in a comprehensive analysis that correlated genetic polymorphisms with the susceptibility of developing RIHT, highlighting its potential influence as a genetic risk factor in this specific clinical scenario.
title: Prediction of radiation-induced hypothyroidism using radiomic data analysis does not show superiority over standard normal tissue complication models

finding: The significant proxy variant rs12037169 at the GJA5 locus at 1q12 was linked to the axial rate of progression in PD with a Beta of -0.25, SE of 0.04, and a P-value of 3.93e-10. Although not directly assayed in the PPMI data, it replicated across cohorts.
title: Association of genetic variation at the GJA5/ACP6 locus with motor progression in Parkinson’s

finding: The SNP rs115217673 located within the MORN1 gene was significantly associated with motor progression to Hoehn and Yahr stage 3 or greater in PD (HR = 2.76, 95% CI 1.97 to 3.87, p = 3.1 x 10^-9), highlighting its potential role in the progression of the disease.
title: Genome-wide determinants of mortality and motor progression in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs301817 was identified as strongly associated with total brain volume in the context of habitual daytime napping. In sensitivity analyses, after addressing potential unbalanced horizontal pleiotropy, it remained associated with total brain volume, suggesting a positive relationship between this genetic variant and larger total brain volume.
title: Is there an association between daytime napping, cognitive function and brain volume? A Mendelian randomisation study in the UK Biobank

finding: The study revealed that the diplotype combination 677CC+1298AC significantly increased the risk of breast cancer, with an odds ratio of 2.553 (95% CI: 1.177-5.541). This finding suggests that the rs1801133 SNP in the MTHFR gene may play a role in breast cancer susceptibility within the studied South-Asian population.
title: Independent, Diplotype and Haplotype Association Analyses of the Selected MTHFR SNPs with the Risk of Breast Cancers in a South-Asian Population

finding: The ANGPTL3 rs34483103 variant, which is a deletion in the 3 prime UTR, was associated with cardiometabolic outcomes in a phenome-wide Mendelian randomization analysis. Specifically, it demonstrated an odds ratio of 0.79 per allele for coronary artery disease (CAD) protection, indicating that inactivation of ANGPTL3 reduced CAD risk.
title: Drug-target Mendelian randomization analysis supports lowering plasma ANGPTL3, ANGPTL4, and APOC3 levels as strategies for reducing cardiovascular disease risk

finding: The SNP rs9436127 was previously reported and replicated in a prior study for its association with SGIT, showing underlying genetic mechanisms relevant to chronic back pain.
title: Decomposing the genetic background of chronic back pain

finding: The RHD*weak D type 4.0 allele (rs1053355) was observed in 10 individuals in a homozygous state, which is responsible for the weak expression of the D antigen, often mistyped as D- in serological tests.
title: A comprehensive characterization of blood group antigen variants in the Middle Eastern population genomes - Insights into genetic epidemiology

finding: The rare low frequency antigen Cw+ (Rh8 - rs138268848) was found in about 0.17% of Middle Eastern populations, which has serious transfusion implications including hemolytic disease of the newborn when mismatched.
title: A comprehensive characterization of blood group antigen variants in the Middle Eastern population genomes - Insights into genetic epidemiology

finding: The SNP rs12075, located in the ACKR1 gene, was associated with elevated circulatory levels of several chemokines including CCL2/MCP-1, CCL7/MCP-3, CCL11/eotaxin-1, CXCL1/GROa, and CXCL8/IL-8. This missense variant resulted in less effective chemokine binding to the ACKR1 receptor due to a loss of a necessary amino-acid sulfation. The impaired receptor binding might have led to a compensatory increase in ACKR1 expression, contributing to the positive association observed between genetically proxied ACKR1 levels and its ligands. This finding related to the inflammatory responses mediated by cytokine interactions, illustrating the role of ACKR1 as a scavenger receptor for chemokines.
title: The Genomic Architecture of Circulating Cytokine Levels Points to Drug Targets for Immune-Related Diseases

finding: The associated variant rs72744832, which is an intronic variant in LMOD1, demonstrated a significant association with transient global amnesia (TGA) and an odds ratio of 1.41. It did not associate with other diseases, suggesting specificity for TGA. Additionally, while LMOD1 expressed strongly in arterial tissues, quantitative trait analysis did not establish a connection between the variant and regulation of LMOD1 expression. Moreover, this SNP was linked to lean mass phenotypes in the UK Biobank.
title: Genetics of transient amnesia highlights a vascular role in memory

finding: The rs4265380 variant, despite being in the trans region for the gene RUNX3, showed significant association with the prioritized IL22RA2 gene in the novel AD GWAS locus. It had support from both cis and trans pQTL signals, linking it to critical inflammatory pathways in atopic dermatitis.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome-Wide Association Meta-Analysis Identifies Novel Loci in Atopic Dermatitis

finding: The SNP rs12041051 was associated with predictive models for treatment outcomes in pancreatic cancer. Variants at this SNP highlighted the relationship between gene mutations and tumor characteristics that could lead to poorer prognoses for patients.
title: radioGWAS: link radiome to genome to discover driver genes with somatic mutations for heterogeneous tumor image phenotype in pancreatic cancer

finding: The rs60642321 SNP was associated with CFHR1 plasma levels, indicating a role in plasma protein variability, and was recognized previously in blood-related studies.
title: Integrative genetic and immune cell analysis of plasma proteins in healthy donors identifies novel associations involving primary immune deficiency genes

finding: The rs2504780 SNP showed a significant association with reduced Ficolin-3 plasma levels, indicating its potential role as a risk factor for Ficolin-3 deficiency.
title: Integrative genetic and immune cell analysis of plasma proteins in healthy donors identifies novel associations involving primary immune deficiency genes

finding: This variant was associated with variations in serum levels of biomarkers and indicated a critical role in influencing biological pathways.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: rs7512140 impacted the expression of genes related to immune responses, specifically within the FCGR2B/FCRLB loci, further evidencing its role in the genetic regulation of immune parameters in T1D.
title: Genetic factors affecting immune phenotypes in type 1 diabetes

finding: rs1518110 had an association with IL10 gene expression, supporting its relevance in regulating immune responses involved in T1D.
title: Genetic factors affecting immune phenotypes in type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs4660756 was uniquely identified by the ADuLT GWAS approach when analyzing ADHD. The closest gene, ST3GAL3, had previous associations with both educational attainment and ADHD.
title: ADuLT: An efficient and robust time-to-event GWAS

finding: The SNP rs11810109 was identified by SPACox as associated with ADHD through the gene ST3GAL3. Notably, it was not detected by the ADuLT method, highlighting differences in genetic association detection between methods.
title: ADuLT: An efficient and robust time-to-event GWAS

finding: The variant rs3768321 in the PABPC4 gene was associated with a reduction in heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) risk, showing directionally concordant results with decreased levels of body mass index (BMI), risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), and renal failure. Genetic ablation of PABPC4 in mice supported these findings by showing changes in metabolic traits.
title: Large-scale Mendelian randomization identifies novel pathways as therapeutic targets for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and with preserved ejection fraction

finding: The SNP rs75057517 was identified within the deletion CNVR at 1q22.1, which is known for its association with neurodevelopmental disorders and intellectual disability. A p-value of 0.0001 was reported in a GWAS of general intelligence, indicating its impact on cognitive abilities.
title: The copy number variant architecture of psychopathology and cognitive development in the ABCD® study

finding: The lead SNP rs6701496 was associated with the INAVA gene, showing a significant association with anterior uveitis (OR = 0.91, p = 1.03 × 10−8). This association was particularly strong in the FinnGen dataset (OR = 0.90, p = 2.99 × 10−7), and was also linked with inflammatory bowel disease and various colitis types, solidifying its role in immune-related conditions.
title: Genome-wide association study of anterior uveitis

finding: Located within the INAVA gene, SNP rs296520 was in linkage disequilibrium with rs6701496 and displayed a significant association (p = 6.6 × 10−8) related to anterior uveitis. This missense variant was also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, highlighting its importance in innate immunity and inflammation.
title: Genome-wide association study of anterior uveitis

finding: The locus near OR2L13/NLRP3 contained SNP rs145759877, which was found to be significantly associated with anterior uveitis (OR = 6.49, p = 3.7 × 10−19). This association was predominantly driven by the FinnGen dataset (OR = 8.44, p = 6.38 × 10−19), indicating its relevance to inflammation and immune regulation.
title: Genome-wide association study of anterior uveitis

finding: The rs2228145 SNP, known to have a functional effect on IL6R, was analyzed in the context of its association with sepsis outcomes. The findings indicated that IL6R blockade, which this SNP contributed to evaluating, was causally associated with reduced incidence of sepsis, with a notable decrease in critical care admissions and sepsis-related mortality. This effect was demonstrated through odds ratios (OR) indicating a protective effect, with the magnitude of these associations suggesting that IL6R blockade may confer benefits similar to those seen in severe COVID-19 outcomes. The consistent results across various analyses indicated the robustness of the findings.
title: Therapeutic potential of IL6R blockade for the treatment of sepsis and sepsis-related death: Findings from a Mendelian randomisation study

finding: The SNP rs76859653, located on chromosome 1 in the HMCN1 gene, was significantly associated with lower one-year cognitive performance in Attention, Processing speed, and Executive function (APE) among breast cancer patients compared to controls, with a p-value of 1.624×10⁻⁸. This suggests that carrying the minor allele may increase the risk of cognitive decline over time in cancer patients.
title: Genetic variants associated with longitudinal cognitive performance in older breast cancer patients and controls

finding: The rs12117661 SNP was used as a genetic instrument for PCSK9 expression, with a strong association (p = 8.31E-11). This analysis aimed to determine whether genetic associations linked to statins were independent of cholesterol-lowering effects.
title: Using Genomic data to Investigate the Anti-Depressive Effects of Statins

finding: This SNP was linked with PIGC splicing through an sQTL, suggesting that changes in PIGC could influence POAG risk in the identified locus.
title: Integrating genetic regulation and single-cell expression with GWAS prioritizes causal genes and cell types for glaucoma

finding: Identified as having a secondary haplotype in association with POAG risk, this SNP provided more insight into the genetic architecture of the disease.
title: Integrating genetic regulation and single-cell expression with GWAS prioritizes causal genes and cell types for glaucoma

finding: Significant in the European population, this SNP was part of a locus associated with POAG, which expanded understanding of population-specific genetic contributions.
title: Integrating genetic regulation and single-cell expression with GWAS prioritizes causal genes and cell types for glaucoma

finding: The SNP rs6689226 was identified as a novel anxiety-associated locus located in an intergenic region downstream of the LINC01360 gene on chromosome 1, with a beta of 0.01 and a p-value of 4.8×10^-12. This variant was highlighted as the strongest association within the anxiety genome-wide association study conducted in individuals of European ancestry.
title: Gene Discovery and Biological Insights into Anxiety Disorders from a Multi-Ancestry Genome-wide Association Study of >1.2 Million Participants

finding: The study found that the rs1205 T-Dom genotype in the CRP gene was significantly associated with COVID-19 death or hospitalization, with an odds ratio of 1.859 (95% CI 1.001-3.453, p=0.049) after adjusting for age, sex, center, body mass index, and a history of cardiovascular disease. Within the younger participants, the association was even stronger, showing an odds ratio of 2.857 (95% CI 1.108-7.362, p=0.030). This finding established rs1205 as a potential genetic risk factor influencing COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Genetic Variant rs1205 is Associated with COVID-19 Outcomes: The Strong Heart Study and Strong Heart Family Study

finding: SNP rs5779595 was noted in the female-specific analysis within the LRMDA gene, achieving a significant p-value of 4.04 x 10^-8, marking its importance in the context of widespread pain in females.
title: Genome-Wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Widespread Pain in the UK Biobank (N=172,230)

finding: This intronic variant in WNT4 was associated with three categories of female infertility, showing odds ratios of F-ALL=0.909, F-EXCL=0.923, and F-INCL=0.870, highlighting its relevance across various infertility phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide analyses identify 21 infertility loci and over 400 reproductive hormone loci across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: The SNP rs4845604 was identified as having a significant association with eczema/dermatitis through its overlap with a detected ROH diplotype at chr1:151515188-151902494. This finding aligned with previous GWAS results concerning the identified phenotype, showcasing the relevance of this SNP in relation to non-cancerous diseases and connecting the detection of haplotypes to specific health outcomes.
title: Discovery of runs-of-homozygosity diplotype clusters and their associations with diseases in UK Biobank

finding: The rs34612342 SNP was found to be a mutation in the MUTYH gene, which is linked to colorectal cancer. This identification of a genetic risk factor was crucial for understanding potential interventions and preventive measures for the participants involved.
title: Cohort profile: The I AM Frontier prospective cohort study in Flanders

finding: The rs1801274 variant was identified as a pQTL associated with IgGFcRII-b, and its G-allele was linked to susceptibility to autoimmune diseases, indicating its relevance in the context of immune response.
title: Genetic regulation of the plasma proteome and its link to cardiometabolic disease in Greenlandic Inuit

finding: This SNP was identified as part of the most significant risk locus for microarchitectural deterioration located in chromosome 1p31.3, with a P-value of 2.14×10^-32. This association reflected its strong linkage with bone microarchitecture.
title: Genetic Determinants of Bone Microarchitecture and its Association with Health Outcomes: A Genome-wide Association and Mendelian Randomization Study on Trabecular Bone Score

finding: Alongside rs7062, this SNP was part of the significant locus in chromosome 1p31.3, showing a strong association with TBS and bone microarchitectural changes, indicated by a P-value of 2.14×10^-32.
title: Genetic Determinants of Bone Microarchitecture and its Association with Health Outcomes: A Genome-wide Association and Mendelian Randomization Study on Trabecular Bone Score

finding: This SNP was also included in the significant locus on chromosome 1p31.3, with a strong association to TBS, featured with a P-value of 2.14×10^-32, highlighting its critical role in influencing bone microstructure.
title: Genetic Determinants of Bone Microarchitecture and its Association with Health Outcomes: A Genome-wide Association and Mendelian Randomization Study on Trabecular Bone Score

finding: The variant rs553741 was associated with liver-derived PCSK9 expression and showed evidence of a shared genetic variant affecting both PCSK9 expression and prostate cancer risk during colocalization analyses. The posterior probability of colocalization was 0.103, suggesting a potential shared causal variant at this locus.
title: Genetically proxied PCSK9 inhibition provides indication of lower prostate cancer risk: a Mendelian randomization study

finding: The F5 variant was identified as protective against pulmonary embolism and correlated with reductions in plasma F5 levels, countering risks associated with other known mutations.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The intergenic variant was validated as an association signal in AF risk analyses, showing a link to cardiac rhythm influences.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: A rare missense variant in METTL11B was identified as having increased risk for atrial fibrillation, supporting its role in cardiac molecular mechanisms.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The study identified rs61748535 as a missense mutation (c.574G>A; p.(Ala192Thr)) in the ABCA4 gene, which was deemed probably damaging and disease-causing according to PolyPhen-2 and MutationTaster, though SIFT categorized it as tolerated. This mutation was classified as rare in population databases and was verified in an individual from family 9.
title: ABCA4-Related Retinopathies in Lebanon: a novel mutation and significant heterogeneity

finding: The SNP rs61749417 was recognized as another missense mutation (c.1927G>A; p.(Val643Met)) in the ABCA4 gene. This mutation was also considered probably damaging and disease-causing by the predictive tools used. It appeared as rare in multiple population databases and was detected in the same patient as rs61748535, showcasing its co-segregation.
title: ABCA4-Related Retinopathies in Lebanon: a novel mutation and significant heterogeneity

finding: The mutation at rs1800553 (c.5882G>A; p.(Gly1961Glu)) was identified as a homozygous alteration in family 31. It was reported as rare across various population databases and was predicted to be damaging and disease-causing. This mutation was a known variant in exon 42, verified through Sanger sequencing in the affected individual.
title: ABCA4-Related Retinopathies in Lebanon: a novel mutation and significant heterogeneity

finding: The study reported the nonsense mutation at rs61751383 (c.6088C>T; p.(Arg2030Ter)) found in family 37. This mutation was characterized as rare and had predicted damaging effects. It was validated through Sanger sequencing, with parents being heterozygous carriers. This variant was noted as known in the literature.
title: ABCA4-Related Retinopathies in Lebanon: a novel mutation and significant heterogeneity

finding: The SNP rs61751398 represented a homozygous missense mutation (c.3259G>A; p.(Glu1087Lys)) identified in family 58. This mutation was found to be likely damaging and disease-causing according to the predictive analyses. It was classified as rare without previous homozygous reports, and co-segregation with the disease was established in the proband.
title: ABCA4-Related Retinopathies in Lebanon: a novel mutation and significant heterogeneity

finding: This SNP was associated with Transgelin-2 (TAGLN2), which was identified as a potential drug target for MI.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization Analysis Identified Potential Drug Targets for Myocardial Infarction

finding: This SNP was associated with PCSK9, a protein that exhibited significant genetically predicted causal association with MI risk.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization Analysis Identified Potential Drug Targets for Myocardial Infarction

finding: This SNP was also linked to PCSK9, emphasizing its relevance as a potential target for MI treatment.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization Analysis Identified Potential Drug Targets for Myocardial Infarction

finding: This SNP was included in the associations with PCSK9, aligning with its role as a candidate for therapeutic intervention in MI.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization Analysis Identified Potential Drug Targets for Myocardial Infarction

finding: This SNP was additionally associated with PCSK9, contributing to its identification as a promising drug target for MI.
title: Proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization Analysis Identified Potential Drug Targets for Myocardial Infarction

finding: The SNP rs7525578 near the RAP1A gene on chromosome 1p13.2 was identified as a novel locus significantly associated with AF, showing the strongest association with a P-value of 1.24×10^-26. The odds ratio for this SNP was 2.74, suggesting a strong effect on increasing AF risk.
title: Identification of two new genetic loci associated with atrial fibrillation in the Taiwanese population-implication of metabolism and fibrosis in atrial fibrillation mechanism

finding: The variant E326K (rs2230288) was part of the combined analysis of the GBA gene variants associated with increased odds of Parkinson's disease (PD). It contributed to the GBA carrier status, indicating a reduction in GCase activity by 18–46%, which was linked with a higher risk of PD.
title: Gene-environment interactions for Parkinson’s disease

finding: The variant T369M (rs75548401) was aggregated with other GBA variants into a single carrier status, correlating with increased odds of PD. This variant also contributed to the observed decreased GCase activity, further establishing its association with the risk of developing PD.
title: Gene-environment interactions for Parkinson’s disease

finding: The variant N370S (rs76763715) was included in the analysis of GBA risk-associated variants and thus was associated with higher PD odds. The inclusion in the binary classification as a GBA carrier highlighted its role in reducing GCase activity, which is critical for PD susceptibility.
title: Gene-environment interactions for Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs10157379 variant was associated with the presence of SARS, and the CT genotype was positively linked to increased SARS severity. It played a significant role in predicting critical COVID-19 outcomes, indicating that NLRP3 variants are involved in the response to SARS-CoV-2.
title: In COVID-19, NLRP3 inflammasome genetic variants are associated with critical disease and these effects are partly mediated by the sickness symptom complex: a nomothetic network approach

finding: The rs10754558 variant was significantly associated with SSC, where the CG genotype was inversely correlated with SSC severity. This variant also positively impacted the risk of critical COVID-19, indicating a mediating role by attenuating SSC, which itself provided protection against severe COVID-19 outcomes.
title: In COVID-19, NLRP3 inflammasome genetic variants are associated with critical disease and these effects are partly mediated by the sickness symptom complex: a nomothetic network approach

finding: This SNP was associated with time until relapse to heavy drinking (THR) in patients treated with naltrexone, showing strong evidence of association (p=3.9E-08) and indicating a potential role in medication-specific response.
title: Genetic Contributions to Alcohol Use Disorder Treatment Outcomes: A Genome-wide Pharmacogenomics Study

finding: The missense variant rs188273166 in SLC30A10 showed strong association with higher corrected T1 liver iron, with an effect of 63.72 milliseconds and an effect size of 1.18 standard deviations (P = 2.1 × 10^-22). This finding corresponded with reported roles of SLC30A10 in manganese regulation and iron metabolism.
title: Mapping rare protein-coding variants on multi-organ imaging traits

finding: This SNP was identified as a potentially novel locus near DHRS3, showing a rare allele frequency of 0.06% in European ancestries and 9.0% in African ancestry cohorts, emphasizing the significance of multi-ancestry analysis.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs12071817 was found in the study referenced by Mirchia et al. (2020) to have relevance in the mutational profile of adult diffuse gliomas. An increase in MUC17 methylation associated with this SNP correlated with higher malignancy grades of gliomas, indicating a connection to poorer prognosis for patients.
title: MUC17 mutations and methylation are associated with poor prognosis in adult-type diffuse glioma patients

finding: The analysis suggested a potential gene-by-smoking interaction for the cardiac-specific RYR2 gene related to rs6698949, linked to ischemic heart disease risk. The analysis indicated that certain ICD10 codes were associated with the genetic findings, hypothesizing a mechanism whereby smoking might amplify ischemic risk through non-atherosclerotic pathways.
title: Improving Genetic Association Studies with a Novel Methodology that Unveils the Hidden Complexity of All-Cause Heart Failure

finding: The SNP rs10789158 exhibited borderline significant association with AML regardless of subtype, with an OR of 1.22 and a P-value of 2.25 × 10^-7, mapped to the CACHD1 gene on 1p31.3.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies susceptibility loci for acute myeloid leukemia

finding: The SNP rs10900585 was confirmed to be associated with severe malaria (SM) in a Senegalese cohort, showing a significant association with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.94. The TT genotype was found to be more frequent among cases than controls.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: SNP rs11240734 was identified as a significant regulatory variant associated with SM, with a combined odds ratio of 2.52 when comparing the homozygous genotype for major alleles versus the minor alleles. It was found to significantly affect the disease outcome among individuals in the Senegalese population.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: The SNP rs1541252 was significantly associated with SM with an odds ratio of 2.52, showing that individuals with specific genotypes for this SNP were more likely to develop severe malaria.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: SNP rs1541253 was associated with SM, with a reported odds ratio of 2.52, indicating a positive association with severe malaria susceptibility among genotyped subjects.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: The SNP rs1541254 exhibited a strong association with SM, having an odds ratio of 2.52, suggesting that this variant may play a significant role in malaria susceptibility.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: SNP rs1541255 was also significantly associated with SM in the Senegalese population, contributing to an overall association with an odds ratio of 2.52 along with the other ATP2B4 SNPs.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: The regulatory SNP rs10751450 was significantly associated with SM, resulting in an odds ratio of 2.07, suggesting a strong impact on the disease risk.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: SNP rs10751451 showed a significant association with SM with an odds ratio of 2.49, indicating its relevance in malaria susceptibility.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: The SNP rs10751452 was found to have a significant association with SM, with an odds ratio of 2.27, reinforcing its role as a regulatory variant influencing the disease.
title: Identification of ATP2B4 regulatory element containing functional genetic variants associated with severe malaria

finding: The SNP rs10927887 was suggested to be associated with heart failure through a prior candidate-variant study. This common coding variant was implicated in altering function within the ClC-Ka chloride channel, contributing to a cardiac-renal axis in heart failure.
title: Multi-ancestry Multivariate Genome-Wide Analysis Highlights the Role of Common Genetic Variation in Cardiac Structure, Function, and Heart Failure-related Traits

finding: The analysis of the SNP rs12092460 was linked to the role of CD271 in melanoma. It elucidated the presence of CD271<sup>high</sup> subtypes of melanoma brain metastases that showed therapy resistance, thus proposing a connection between this SNP and increased progression of brain metastases.
title: Decoding molecular programs in melanoma brain metastases

finding: The finding indicated that male patients homozygous for the SELP rs6127 (p.Asp603Asn) variant were more prone to COVID-19-related thrombosis due to the mutation making the Selectin P protein more liable to cause clot formation, showing a connection to disease severity.
