title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: This novel SNP rs138233898 was linked to hsCRP as discovered in the GWAS, highlighting its relevance in the study.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: Identified as a novel SNP in the study, rs189750399 was associated with hsCRP levels, suggesting its significant role in the underlying biological mechanisms.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: This SNP was identified as the most significant hsCRP-associated SNP, demonstrating a strong association with chronic inflammation.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs629301 was linked to the gene CELSR2, which was previously associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) through a genome-wide association study (GWAS). It was found that this SNP affects the binding activity of the transcription factor OSR1, which itself was associated with blood pressure, another traditional CAD risk factor. This suggests a potential interaction between traditional risk factors for CAD, namely blood pressure and cholesterol levels, via genomic variation that includes rSNPs.
title: A statistical approach to identify regulatory DNA variations

finding: The SNP rs12092637 was associated with immunogenic cell death (ICD) in cancer therapy, linking it to better immune responses during chemotherapy treatments as reported in the study by Fumet et al. in 2020. This finding highlighted the potential of certain genetic markers in predicting the efficacy of immunotherapy.
title: Ru(II)-Photoactive Agents for Targeting ER Stress and Immunogenic Cell Death

finding: The SNP rs186996510, a known missense variant in EGLN1, was reported to be associated with high-altitude adaptation and hemoglobin levels specifically in Tibetans, indicating its relevance in hematological traits.
title: Trans-ethnic and ancestry-specific blood-cell genetics in 746,667 individuals from 5 global populations

finding: The SNP rs2228145 in the IL6R gene was associated with platelet count in East Asians (p=4.3×10^-6), reinforcing the role of IL6 signaling in platelet biology.
title: Trans-ethnic and ancestry-specific blood-cell genetics in 746,667 individuals from 5 global populations

finding: As an MDD GWAS index SNP, rs301806 was found to likely regulate the nearby gene RERE, demonstrating its involvement in the genetic framework associated with major depressive disorder.
title: Sex significantly impacts the function of major depression-linked variants in vivo

finding: Alongside rs301806, this SNP was found to be functional in regulating RERE, underscoring its significance in the context of MDD-associated loci.
title: Sex significantly impacts the function of major depression-linked variants in vivo

finding: Previously confirmed as functional in classical assays, this SNP was linked to regulatory activity within the context of MDD risk signals.
title: Sex significantly impacts the function of major depression-linked variants in vivo

finding: The SNP rs12082274 was associated with mechanisms of T-Cell exhaustion in pancreatic cancer, as noted in a study led by Saka et al. in 2020. The research indicated that this SNP plays a role in the immune response within the tumor microenvironment, particularly in relation to the adaptations of tumor cells and cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) to metabolic stress such as glutamine depletion.
title: Macropinocytosis controls metabolic stress-driven CAF subtype identity in pancreatic cancer

finding: The rs78037977 variant was established as the highest associated variant in the 1q24.3 T1D associated locus. It overlapped an islet cytokine-induced regulatory element bound by islet-specific transcription factors. The T1D-associated G allele exhibited reduced enhancer activity in response to pro-inflammatory cytokines during luciferase assays compared to the protective A allele, indicating its potential causal role in T1D pathogenesis.
title: The impact of pro-inflammatory cytokines on the β-cell regulatory landscape provides new insights into the genetics of type 1 diabetes

finding: Jointly associated with volumes of pons, SCP, and medulla oblongata, and implicated in both SCZ and bipolar disorder (BD). The nearby gene KCNN3, expressed in the adult brain, encodes a protein that impacts neuronal afterhyperpolarization.
title: The genetic architecture of human brainstem structures and their involvement in common brain disorders

finding: The SNP rs12040825 was linked to the analysis of mitochondrial chaperone-client co-expression. This finding, highlighted in the research conducted by Galai et al. (2020), underscored the importance of chaperone functional partitioning across various types of cancer, suggesting that this SNP could play a role in the cancer-specific metabolic reprogramming.
title: Ecological network analysis reveals cancer-dependent chaperone-client interaction structure and robustness in the mitochondria

finding: The SNP rs872129 was found to be linked to chitinase-3-like protein 1 levels, suggesting a direct molecular association. The SNP is located upstream of the CHI3L1 gene that encodes for this protein. Moreover, IL18, which is involved in macrophage activation and related to juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), was also highlighted as a direct target of IRF1 in the gene regulatory network.
title: Scalable ultra-high-throughput single-cell chromatin and RNA sequencing reveals gene regulatory dynamics linking macrophage polarization to autoimmune disease

finding: The finding related to rs3010185 was document in the context of monitoring the soy moratorium in the Amazon biome using remote sensing images. This SNP played a role in assessing the effectiveness of policy interventions aimed at reducing deforestation associated with soybean cultivation in the Amazon, which highlighted the importance of compliance with environmental regulations.
title: The role of elections as drivers of tropical deforestation

finding: The variant rs12075, also known as the Duffy-null FY*BES allele, was found to confer resistance against Plasmodium vivax infection in sub-Saharan Africans. It was detected in African-descent populations from Madagascar, the Sahel, and Pakistan, showing a high observed frequency of 0.93 compared to an expected frequency of 0.45, with a significance level of P = 3.4×10−9. This finding contributed to the evidence of adaptive admixture, particularly in relation to disease resistance.
title: The genomic signatures of natural selection in admixed human populations

finding: The variant rs755467862, a non-synonymous variant resulting in the amino acid substitution Cys200Tyr in the MEGF6 gene, demonstrated strong evidence of segregation with osteoporosis and osteopenia in a high-risk pedigree. Seven out of eight carriers of this variant had either a physician-confirmed diagnosis of osteoporosis or osteopenia, highlighting its importance in predisposition to these conditions. Furthermore, functional analyses indicated that this variant likely disrupted the structure of an EGF-like calcium-binding domain, potentially reducing the protein's functional capacity.
title: A role for the MEGF6 gene in predisposition to osteoporosis

finding: The SNP rs12030565 was associated with variations related to bird migration patterns, specifically influenced by broad-scale weather patterns during flight. This finding corroborated results from the study by Clipp et al. (2020), which indicated that weather significantly influenced landbird stopover distributions. Hence, rs12030565 played a critical role in understanding how weather can affect avian movement and collision risks during migration.
title: What causes bird-building collision risk? Seasonal dynamics and weather drivers

finding: The SNP rs12123824 was identified in the context of the study as potentially impacting the modulation of the tumor microenvironment through the administration of TLR3 agonists like Nexavant. The findings suggested that this specific SNP could be associated with the variable efficacy observed in tumor growth suppression in various cancer models when using Nexavant, especially in combination with anti-PD-1 therapy.
title: The defined TLR3 agonist, Nexavant, exhibits anti-cancer efficacy and potentiates anti-PD-1 antibody therapy by enhancing immune cell infiltration

finding: The SNP rs1323292 was located within a GATA3-bound enhancer upstream of the gene RGS1. Upon KO of GATA3, chromatin accessibility at this enhancer decreased significantly, alongside diminished expression of RGS1. This finding indicated that the regulatory influence of GATA3 on RGS1 was disrupted due to the presence of the MS-associated SNP, demonstrating the capacity of disease SNPs to affect multiple genes through critical regulatory cascades.
title: Systematic discovery and perturbation of regulatory genes in human T cells reveals the architecture of immune networks

finding: The SNP rs903319 was identified as having evidence of inclusion in a set that indicated a negative relationship in a two-parameter causal model assessing the causal role of cholesterol on age-related macular degeneration. This finding was notable as it represented the only SNP exhibiting such evidence within its smaller set, suggesting a distinct causal effect.
title: Profile-likelihood Bayesian model averaging for two-sample summary data Mendelian randomization in the presence of horizontal pleiotropy

finding: The SNP rs1800896 in the IL10 gene was nominally associated with recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), demonstrating an odds ratio of 1.60 (95% CI: 1.07, 2.42, P=0.025). This suggests that this variant may contribute to an increased risk of RPL within the studied Ukrainian population.
title: Risk of recurrent pregnancy loss in the Ukrainian population using a combined effect of genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs12071733 was associated with the regulation of cholesterol metabolism in CD8(+) T cells, which was linked to anticancer immunity. This finding highlighted the role of the nuclear receptor RORα in cholesterol sensing and its importance in immune responses against cancer.
title: HR3/RORα-mediated cholesterol sensing regulates TOR signaling

finding: In the study, rs941125 was identified as the most strongly associated SNP with glaucoma, reaching a Bonferroni-corrected significance level (P=4.73x10-6) in a meta-analysis of the GERA and UK Biobank cohorts. This SNP localized to intron 1 of GLIS1 and was confirmed to be significantly associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) in multiple independent cohorts. Furthermore, rs941125 was associated with variation in GLIS1 gene expression across several tissues, reinforcing the hypothesis of GLIS1's involvement in glaucoma pathogenesis in humans.
title: GLIS1 regulates trabecular meshwork function and intraocular pressure and is associated with glaucoma in humans

finding: The SNP rs2953329 was discovered as a new risk variant associated with the gene AKT3, suggesting its role in the genetic basis of psychopathology.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: The SNP rs11121821 was linked to pathways involving LSD1/KDM1A, a critical factor in the regulation of cancer stemness and epigenetic alterations related to aging and centromeric function. In the study, it was found that inhibition of LSD1/KDM1A in aged cells led to an increase in centromeric proteins and transcripts, thus rejuvenating the mitotic capabilities of these cells. This suggests an important role for rs11121821 in the modulation of centromeric activity during aging.
title: Unraveling the mechanism of centromere inactivation in human aging

finding: The SNP rs12040964 was linked to the expression and transcriptional activity of SOX2, a crucial factor involved in pediatric sarcoma development. This finding indicated that this SNP had prognostic implications, specifically relating to a subpopulation of cancer stem cells in sarcoma, which correlated with the phenotype of aggressive sarcomas exhibiting high metastatic potential.
title: Dysregulation of the p53 pathway provides a therapeutic target in aggressive pediatric sarcomas with stem-like traits

finding: The SNP rs12071765 was associated with the CCL5/CCR5 axis in cancer progression, particularly in the context of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). It suggested a connection between CCR5 inhibition and improved anti-tumor immunity, indicating that this genetic factor could influence the efficacy of immunotherapy when combined with ionizing radiation (IR).
title: Tissue-resident NK cells support survival in pancreatic cancer through promotion of cDC1-CD8T activity

finding: The SNP rs12061553 was connected to the development and clinical relevance of tissue-resident NK cells in cancer. This suggested that the genetic variant might play a role in shaping the immune landscape of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, especially concerning NK cell functionality and potential therapeutic applications.
title: Tissue-resident NK cells support survival in pancreatic cancer through promotion of cDC1-CD8T activity

finding: The SNP rs72646508 was identified as a low frequency variant (allele frequency <0.01) significant in the meta-analysis, specifically from the American ancestral group. It was unique to this analysis and contributed to insights regarding the ancestral composition of the cohort.
title: Cloud gazing: demonstrating paths for unlocking the value of cloud genomics through cross-cohort analysis

finding: The SNP rs12061381 was associated with the regulation of the tumor suppressor gene, PTEN, particularly in breast cancer. Analysis revealed that this SNP was related to the low splicing efficiency of the PTEN minor intron, which led to the retention of PTEN pre-mRNA and subsequent production of the long noncoding RNA, PINC. The findings underscored the role of genetic variants in the modulation of PTEN expression, linking this alteration to potential tumorigenesis, which emphasizes the relevance of splicing defects in cancer pathogenesis.
title: Premature cleavage and polyadenylation in the minor intron of PTEN modulate its expression and generates a functional long non-coding RNA in breast cancer

finding: This SNP showed significant association with body height and was linked to OSBPL6, a gene implicated in cholesterol homeostasis and possibly height regulation.
title: pCMLM: Genome Wide Association Study of Body Size Traits in Multiple Regions of Yak Based on the Provided Compressed Mixed Linear Model

finding: Associated with chronic inflammatory disease (CRD), this SNP was part of the shared protein interactions noted in the analysis of autoimmune disease pathways.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: Linked to psoriasis (PSO), this SNP contributed to the understanding of pleiotropic SNPs influencing the pathophysiology of multiple autoimmune disorders.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The IL-10 rs3024505 polymorphism was found to be associated with susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) according to a systematic review and meta-analysis conducted by Liu et al. in 2022.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and enriched pathways in inflammatory bowel disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The variant rs6025, known as the Factor V Leiden variant, was associated with blood clotting disorders. This association was established through fine-mapping of the F5 gene locus, which encodes coagulation factor V.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: The variant rs4524 was identified as one of the HR2 haplotype variants that contributed to the activated protein C resistance phenotype, increasing the risk of venous thromboembolism and was captured in the 95% credible set during fine-mapping.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: Like rs4524, the variant rs4525 was part of the HR2 haplotype contributing to clotting disorders. It was also included in the 95% credible set during the fine-mapping analysis.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: The variant rs6033 was identified as another missense variant associated with the HR2 haplotype. It was captured in the 95% credible set from the 'reweighting' approach but was missed by the default approach during fine-mapping.
title: Credible set is sensitive to imputation quality and missing variants

finding: This SNP was classified as a Development Associated Element (DAE) in astrocytes based on H3K79me2 and H4K20me1 presence. It is associated with Parkinson's disease and was replicated in subsequent meta-analyses, indicating its importance in the genetic architecture related to this condition.
title: Minimum entropy framework identifies a novel class of genomic functional elements and reveals regulatory mechanisms at human disease loci

finding: The research indicated that the SNP rs646776 was identified as a regulator of progranulin levels in human plasma. This SNP is located near the gene sortilin, which has implications in various neurodegenerative diseases. The findings were significant as they highlighted the genetic influence on protein levels that could be associated with the pathogenesis of conditions like Alzheimer's disease.
title: Spatially and temporally distinct patterns of expression for VPS10P domain receptors in human cerebral organoids

finding: The research established a significant correlation of the CYP4A11 variant rs9333025 with ischemic stroke susceptibility alongside the CYP4F2 variant rs2108622. This association highlighted the role of both SNPs in influencing 20-HETE levels, which were critical for maintaining autoregulation of cerebral blood flow.
title: 20-HETE-promoted cerebral blow flow autoregulation is associated with enhanced α-smooth muscle actin positive cerebrovascular pericyte contractility

finding: The SNP rs2170336 in the DDOST gene was found to be associated with nephropathy development in individuals with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) based on data from a SNP array involving the FinnDiane population study consisting of 2719 participants.
title: Globally elevating the AGE clearance receptor, OST48, does not protect against the development of diabetic kidney disease, despite improving insulin secretion

finding: The SNP rs12071726 was associated with the oncogenic processes underlying Oral Lichen Planus (OLP) and its potential progression to oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC). It was highlighted in context with the bioinformatics study that revealed significant gene expression patterns related to keratinocyte differentiation and immune response, pointing towards rs12071726's role in the pathology of these conditions.
title: Oral Lichen Planus and its relation with Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma: new insights into the potential for malignant transformation

finding: The variant Gln223Arg (rs1137101) in the LEPR gene did not show a statistically significant effect on BMI when analyzed alone. However, in combination with the ADRB2 variant Gln27Glu (rs1042714), a significant synergistic effect was observed on BMI (beta = 0.04; P value = 0.013). This interaction was especially pronounced in individuals with BMI > 25, where the effect size increased to beta = 0.047 (P value = 0.0056). This finding indicated a linkage between this SNP and obesity risk as part of the genetic interaction with ADRB2 expressions.
title: The perineurium integrates leptin with its sympathetic outflow to protect against obesity

finding: The heterozygous missense variant c.26C>T (p.Thr9Met) in exon 2 of the SLC2A1 gene caused GLUT1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1DS) and was predicted to be damaging based on assessments from nineteen different in silico predictors. This variant was reported as a likely pathogenic mutation and had been noted in an individual with GLUT1DS, who inherited it from an asymptomatic father.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: The identified variant rs80359819 was classified as pathogenic in ClinVar and had previous reports in GLUT1DS patients, marking it as a disease-causing mutation, thus confirming its association with the disease.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: The missense variant c.493G>A (p.Val165Ile) in exon 4 of the SLC2A1 gene was observed in all family members with epilepsy or episodic movement disorders. The variant was classified as pathogenic in ClinVar and linked to GLUT1DS, indicating its significant role in the disease.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: The heterozygous missense variant c.884C>T (p.Thr295Met) in exon 8 of the SLC2A1 gene was evaluated as pathogenic by various predictors. This variant was found to alter GLUT1 conformation and was linked to impaired glucose uptake, being recognized as a disease-causing mutation for GLUT1DS.
title: Molecular genetics of GLUT1DS Italian pediatric cohort: 10 novel related-disease variants and structural analysis

finding: In the analysis, rs76763715 was associated with decreased GCase activity, with a beta of -4.21, standard error of 0.35, and a p-value of 4.55e-31. This SNP is a result of the variant p.N370S within the GBA1 locus.
title: Genome-wide association study of glucocerebrosidase activity modifiers

finding: The SNP rs745550122 was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with the lead SNP in the GBA1 locus, showing a beta of -4.46, standard error of 0.35, and a p-value of 6.61e-34. It also indicated a strong association with decreased GCase activity.
title: Genome-wide association study of glucocerebrosidase activity modifiers

finding: This SNP was in strong linkage disequilibrium with p.E326K and was associated with GCase activity, passing multiple testing correction in the meta-analysis.
title: Genome-wide association study of glucocerebrosidase activity modifiers

finding: This intron variant in the IL23R gene was noted for its involvement in significant interactions linked to Crohn's disease and IBD, establishing its relevance in these pathologies.
title: Detecting Genetic Interactions with Visible Neural Networks

finding: The SNP rs12061473 was associated with BCMA (B-cell maturation antigen) targeting therapies in the context of Multiple Myeloma (MM), as indicated by the cited work of Cho et al. (2020). This association highlighted the potential of using BCMA-targeting strategies as a novel approach in immunotherapy for managing MM, further underscoring the importance of genetic variations in tailoring treatment options for patients.
title: The Sec61 translocon is a therapeutic vulnerability in Multiple Myeloma

finding: The SNP rs12030603 was found to be significantly associated with cancer prognosis in a study, which highlighted its relevance in deep learning approaches predict cancer outcomes.
title: Generalising uncertainty improves accuracy and safety of deep learning analytics applied to oncology

finding: This SNP was noted for its association with increased breast cancer risk while presenting a decrease in ovarian cancer susceptibility.
title: Combining genome-wide studies of breast, prostate, ovarian and endometrial cancers maps cross-cancer susceptibility loci and identifies new genetic associations

finding: The rs6695321 variant located in the CFH locus demonstrated close to genome-wide significance (P=7.0×10^-7, EAF=0.62). The lead variant rs6695321 was in linkage disequilibrium with known CFH variants, reinforcing its relevance in AMD.
title: Chances and challenges of machine learning based disease classification in genetic association studies illustrated on age-related macular degeneration

finding: As a reported independent variant in the CFH locus, rs61818925 was included in the analysis, with its linkage strength to rs6695321 supporting the validity of the genetic association to AMD.
title: Chances and challenges of machine learning based disease classification in genetic association studies illustrated on age-related macular degeneration

finding: Similar to rs61818925, rs570618 was also a reported independent variant in the CFH locus and demonstrated linkage to rs6695321, indicating its role in AMD's genetic landscape.
title: Chances and challenges of machine learning based disease classification in genetic association studies illustrated on age-related macular degeneration

finding: Also located in the CFH locus, rs10922109 showed increased effect estimates in the MLA2 analysis compared to the naïve analysis, which now yielded a nominally significant association of OR=1.15 (P=0.047), indicating its importance in the context of AMD.
title: Chances and challenges of machine learning based disease classification in genetic association studies illustrated on age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs12120626 disrupted STAT3 regulation of CSF3R in the Hippocampus, indicative of its role in neuroinflammatory response linked to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Predicting gene regulatory networks from multi-omics to link genetic risk variants and neuroimmunology to Alzheimer’s disease phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs12040961 was linked to strategies aimed at targeting aldehyde dehydrogenases to eliminate cancer stem cells in gynecologic malignancies. This research contributes to the understanding of cancer stem cell biology and potential therapeutic interventions.
title: Spatially Resolved in vivo CRISPR Screen Sequencing via Perturb-DBiT

finding: The SNP rs12061576 was associated with sorafenib resistance in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) as reported by Cabral et al. This study highlighted the relevance of genetic heterogeneity, suggesting that certain genotypes related to this SNP may influence treatment outcomes.
title: Novel hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) Subtype-Specific Biomarkers

finding: The SNP rs12082296 was linked to transcription factors involved in cancer development and therapy, as indicated in the findings of Vishnoi et al. This association suggested that variability in this SNP could affect transcriptional regulation in HCC.
title: Novel hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) Subtype-Specific Biomarkers

finding: The nonsynonymous rare variant rs34702397 in OCN was noted for converting arginine (R) at position 43 to glutamine (Q) in humans of African ancestry. This variant was nominally associated with insulin sensitivity index and glucose disposal in a small cohort of African Americans, suggesting potential implications for glucose metabolism and insulin response.
title: The half-life of the bone-derived hormone osteocalcin is regulated through O-glycosylation in mice, but not in humans

finding: The study identified the IL-10 polymorphism (rs1800896) as playing a major role in the development of type 2 diabetes. IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that downregulates pro-inflammatory cytokines, thus having a protective effect against the disease. Elevated levels of certain pro-inflammatory interleukins, like IL-6 and TNF-α, have been observed in type 2 diabetes, and changes at this SNP were described as significant in influencing the pathogenesis of the disease.
title: In-silico analysis reveals hub genes and enriched pathways in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

finding: The SNP rs113696793, which represented a D295G substitution, was predicted to have significant damaging effects on the TPO-R structure and function. It was found to locate in the extracellular domain of the TPO-R, potentially affecting thrombopoietin binding and downstream signaling pathways.
title: In silico analysis of Missense Variants in Human MPL Gene Associated with Essential Thrombocythemia

finding: The SNP rs121913611, leading to an R257C substitution, was also identified as highly deleterious, with implications for TPO-R functionality due to its position in the extracellular domain, which could disrupt TPO binding.
title: In silico analysis of Missense Variants in Human MPL Gene Associated with Essential Thrombocythemia

finding: The SNP rs141311765 was linked to the development of essential thrombocythemia, represented by the Y252H substitution, and was concluded to increase thrombopoietin sensitivity. This SNP was among those predicted to significantly impair TPO-R structure and function.
title: In silico analysis of Missense Variants in Human MPL Gene Associated with Essential Thrombocythemia

finding: The SNP rs201101813, represented by a D128Y substitution, was predicted to negatively impact TPO-R structure due to its position in the extracellular domain, which could affect its ability to bind thrombopoietin.
title: In silico analysis of Missense Variants in Human MPL Gene Associated with Essential Thrombocythemia

finding: The SNP rs1999594 was identified as being robustly associated with serum folate. It was also associated with diastolic blood pressure but found little evidence of affecting pan-cancer or site-specific cancer risks.
title: Mendelian randomisation study exploring the associations of serum folate with pan and site-specific cancers

finding: SNP rs7545014 was associated with serum folate levels and platelet measures. Similar to rs1801133, the evidence suggested it did not significantly affect cancer risk, aligning with the overall study findings of minimal risk associations.
title: Mendelian randomisation study exploring the associations of serum folate with pan and site-specific cancers

finding: The SNP rs12082046 was examined in the context of somatic mutations in collagen genes associated with stomach adenocarcinomas. It was noted that collagen mutations, including those like rs12082046, were prevalent in stomach cancer and were linked to overall survival outcomes. The findings suggested that mutations in collagen genes could serve as significant markers for tumor progression and response to treatment.
title: Somatic Mutations in Collagens are Associated with a Distinct Tumor Environment and Overall Survival in Gastric Cancer

finding: Initially, rs2476601 was one of two variants in a credible set but was later refined to be the only variant remaining after correction. This missense variant, known as R620W, is located in the PTPN22 gene and presented a corrected coverage estimate of 0.9501.
title: Improving the coverage of credible sets in Bayesian genetic fine-mapping

finding: This SNP was also identified as positively and originally related to resistance mechanisms in GBM to temozolomide. It contributed to the understanding of how GBM cell lines exhibit variable sensitivity to chemotherapy in the context of pericyte interaction in a 3D model.
title: Microphysiological system modeling pericyte-induced temozolomide resistance in glioblastoma

finding: The rs61778523 variant within the KIF17 gene was associated with AlkPhos levels, representing a strong and novel association that replicated in meta-analysis.
title: Mendelian pathway analysis of laboratory traits reveals distinct roles for ciliary subcompartments in common disease pathogenesis

finding: This variant was significantly associated with GGT levels in the LUZP1 gene, contributing to the understanding of ciliary gene functions in metabolic contexts.
title: Mendelian pathway analysis of laboratory traits reveals distinct roles for ciliary subcompartments in common disease pathogenesis

finding: The rs1208930 variant within LUZP1 also showed significant association with serum creatinine levels, extending the previously known connections of this gene.
title: Mendelian pathway analysis of laboratory traits reveals distinct roles for ciliary subcompartments in common disease pathogenesis

finding: The SNP rs1885276 was found to be significantly associated with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), reporting an association signal of 4.157e-09. In the context of the study, this SNP was identified as overlapping with SNP anchors in GM12878 cells, suggesting its relevance in the regulatory landscape of IBD-related gene expression.
title: GTAGMe-seq: joint profiling of genetic variants, DNA methylation, GpC methyltransferase footprints, and 3D genome in the same DNA molecules

finding: The SNP rs146774384, representing the variant p.R78C, was found in one PD case, suggesting its potential role as a risk factor for Parkinson's disease.
title: Nanopore sequencing of the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene in a New Zealand Parkinson’s disease cohort

finding: The SNP rs147138516, corresponding to the variant p.D179H, was detected in one case and occurred on the same haplotype as p.E365K, indicating shared genetic risk factors in the cohort.
title: Nanopore sequencing of the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene in a New Zealand Parkinson’s disease cohort

finding: The variant was associated with IL6R and showed an inverse relationship with coronary heart disease and rheumatoid arthritis, illustrating its multifaceted phenotypic effects.
title: Genetic architecture of host proteins interacting with SARS-CoV-2

finding: The SNP rs11121869 was associated with protein-protein interactions (PPIs) in a study of Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The findings illustrated that this SNP, located in a non-coding RNA or regulatory region, demonstrated strong influence on PPI networks, reinforcing the notion that such SNPs can have significant effects, comparable to those found in protein-coding regions. This discovery contributed to understanding the genetic determinants of complex traits through protein interaction quantitative trait locus (piQTL) mapping.
title: Genetic landscape of an in vivo protein interactome

finding: rs74460673 was at gene TMEM39B and was associated with long sleep duration of more than 10 hours. It was noted for previous associations with BMI.
title: Automated Feature Extraction from Population Wearable Device Data Identified Novel Loci Associated with Sleep and Circadian Rhythms

finding: The SNP rs2487451 was found to overlap with non-classical Monocyte CAMBUS+ OCR, marking it as a candidate causal variant within the FCGR region for Albumin/Globulin ratio. This variant was unique to non-classical monocytes and was associated with the nearby FCGR3B gene that encodes a receptor known to be expressed in these cells.
title: Predicted constrained accessible regions mark regulatory elements and causal variants

finding: The SNP rs12071768 was associated with IGF-1R/mTOR-targeted therapy in Ewing sarcoma (EwS). The study by Amin et al. (2020) revealed that this SNP related to the effectiveness of treatments targeting IGF-1R, indicating its role in influencing patient responses to therapies.
title: YAP1 is a key regulator of EWS::FLI1-dependent malignant transformation upon IGF-1 mediated reprogramming of bone mesenchymal stem cells

finding: The SNP rs12030644 was positively linked to EWSR1-FLI1 and EWSR1-ERG positive Ewing sarcoma as identified by Orth et al. (2020). This finding highlighted the specificity of this SNP in identifying Ewing sarcoma subtypes, contributing to understanding disease variants and potential for targeted therapy.
title: YAP1 is a key regulator of EWS::FLI1-dependent malignant transformation upon IGF-1 mediated reprogramming of bone mesenchymal stem cells

finding: The variant rs1412825 was negatively associated with the expression of the gene PPP2R3C in both oligodendrocytes and D1/D2 MSNs. This finding, alongside the previously noted decreased expression of PPP2R3C in AUD individuals, suggests that PPP2R3C may serve a protective role against the development of AUD.
title: Integrated Single-Cell Multiomic Profiling of Caudate Nucleus Suggests Key Mechanisms in Alcohol Use Disorder

finding: The SNP was part of the JPT/CHB-LINC01527 haplotype, which exhibited positive selection in the JPT/CHB population, overlapping with the SMCP IVL region.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP was included in the JPT/CHB-LINC01527 haplotype that was positively selected, indicative of successful adaptation in the context studied.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP was a tagging site for the CEU-IVL haplotype that showed a direct positive correlation with increased IVL expression at northern latitudes in European populations, indicating positive selection.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP was part of the JPT/CHB-SMCP-IVL haplotype, associated with significantly decreased IVL expression, and represented a positive original finding in the context of differential gene regulation.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP was associated with significantly decreased enhancer activity and reduced IVL expression, highlighting its role in atopic dermatitis cases, suggesting positive selection against the allele.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP was noted as a strong candidate for a causal variant linked to increased transcription of IVL, marking it as a significant finding in the context of positive selection.
title: An enhancer:involucrin regulatory module impacts human skin barrier adaptation out-of-Africa and modifies atopic dermatitis risk

finding: The SNP rs12082287 was associated with cancer growth, specifically in the context of fascin inhibitors' effects on certain cancer subtypes. The study revealed that targeting fascin through its inhibitors could significantly decrease the growth of these specific cancer types, providing evidence that variants within this locus could influence cancer progression and response to treatment.
title: Anchorage-independent cell proliferation promoted by fascin’s F-actin bundling

finding: The SNP rs74767794 was specified as a PBS-specific sQTL that colocalized with the THR GWAS signal (index variant rs1327123), suggesting a direct role in influencing collagen-related pathways relevant to OA.
title: Response splicing QTLs in primary human chondrocytes identifies putative osteoarthritis risk genes

finding: The index variant rs1327123 associated with the THR GWAS signal linked to sQTL rs74767794, further highlighting its role in the splicing landscape around OA-related genes.
title: Response splicing QTLs in primary human chondrocytes identifies putative osteoarthritis risk genes

finding: Research previously revealed that the rs11583641 OA risk allele was associated with increased COLGALT2 expression through DNA methylation changes, demonstrating potential links to splicing mechanisms in OA.
title: Response splicing QTLs in primary human chondrocytes identifies putative osteoarthritis risk genes

finding: The SNP rs12123812 was associated with the wide expression of embryonic germline genes in tumors. This association highlighted the developmental similarities between early embryogenesis and the cellular processes regulated by the circadian clock in cancer, particularly concerning telomere dynamics.
title: Role of the circadian clock “Death-Loop” in the DNA damage response underpinning cancer treatment resistance

finding: The non-coding variant rs3790604 in WNT2B was associated with an increased risk of developing primary aldosteronism (PA). This was validated in an independent case-controlled multi-ancestry cohort derived from the All of Us Database, which included 271 cases of PA and matched controls. The A allele of rs3790604 was shown to have an odds ratio of 1.53 for the risk of PA, indicating that individuals carrying this allele had a higher likelihood of developing the condition, consistent with prior findings that linked this variant to PA risk.
title: Non-canonical Wnt signaling triggered by WNT2B drives adrenal aldosterone production

finding: The SNP rs10911362 in the human NCF2 gene was associated with a protective effect against pulmonary TB, as it lowered the odds ratio of the disease. The context of this finding related to the mouse model, where the absence of the Ncf2 gene impaired resistance to M. tuberculosis infection but did not affect overall survival due to compensatory mechanisms by T cell mediated immunity. This suggests that NCF2 is an important genetic factor in the susceptibility to pulmonary TB.
title: Systems genetics uncover new loci containing functional gene candidates in Mycobacterium tuberculosis-infected Diversity Outbred mice

finding: The GLUL rs10911021 SNP was found to be prospectively associated with cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in individuals with type 2 diabetes during the Look AHEAD Study, indicating its importance in cardiovascular health.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The rs3123554 polymorphism in the CNR2 gene was reported to affect body weight and insulin resistance in obese subjects, indicating its relevance in metabolic syndromes.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: SNP rs3024496 in IL10 was established as an eQTL that modulated IL10 expression, with a distribution variance between Memphis (39% TT, 47% CT, 14% CC) and Nicaragua (67% TT, 32% CT, 1% CC). It was correlated with hospitalization and symptom severity during influenza infection, leading to the conclusion that the CC genotype had higher promoter activity compared to the T alleles.
title: Integrated Drivers of Basal and Acute Immunity in Diverse Human Populations

finding: The SNP rs12071822 was associated with metabolic shifts in cancer, particularly in the context of redox homeostasis and therapeutic strategies targeting these metabolic vulnerabilities in prostate cancer.
title: Design, Synthesis, and Efficacy of Novel Trojan Horse Compounds Targeting Metabolic Vulnerabilities in Prostate Cancer

finding: The SNP rs12040900 was found to be relevant in the lipidome analysis of prostatic adenocarcinoma, highlighting the significance of fatty acids in the cancer cell membrane composition.
title: Design, Synthesis, and Efficacy of Novel Trojan Horse Compounds Targeting Metabolic Vulnerabilities in Prostate Cancer

finding: The single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs1797052 was associated with altered visual contrast sensitivity, which is known to be an endophenotype for schizophrenia and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This SNP is located in the 5’-untranslated region of the PDZK1 gene, positioned in a genomic susceptibility region on chromosome 1q21.1, identified as a high-risk locus for these neurodevelopmental disorders. Each additional copy of the minor allele of rs1797052 was shown to increase sensitivity by more than half a standard deviation. The study's findings indicated that pdzk1-knockout (KO) zebrafish exhibited enhanced contrast sensitivity, supporting the genetic link between PDZK1 and visual deficits observed in schizophrenia and ASD.
title: Altered visual function in a larval zebrafish knockout of neurodevelopmental risk gene pdzk1

finding: The SNP rs1048238 was associated with hypertension and affected the central guanine of a pG4 G-tract in the 3'UTR of HSPB7. The analysis showed substantial allelic imbalance towards the alternative allele in heterozygous individuals, indicating that disruption of the pG4 sequence by this variant likely increased gene expression of HSPB7, which is consistent with prior findings that 3'UTR pG4 eQTLs increase gene expression.
title: Integrative analysis reveals RNA G-Quadruplexes in UTRs are selectively constrained and enriched for functional associations

finding: The SNP had noteworthy representation with a minor allele frequency positioning it among significant loci for genetic analysis.
title: The forensic landscape and the population genetic analyses of Hainan Li based on massively parallel sequencing DNA profiling

finding: In the context of cancer research, rs12061439 was highlighted as a SNP associated with SPON2, which was shown to be upregulated through the notch signaling pathway and played a role in promoting tumor progression specifically in gastric cancer. This finding underscored the relevance of this SNP in understanding the genetic factors influencing cancer development.
title: A consensus single-cell transcriptomic atlas of dermal fibroblast heterogeneity

finding: The study observed that rs679515 was an eQTL for Complement Receptor 1 (CR1) expression specifically in oligodendrocytes. The minor allele T, identified as the Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk allele, was associated with higher CR1 expression. Additionally, a significant association was found between rs679515 major allele dosage and lower hematocrit levels in AD patients, indicating a relationship between this SNP and hematological traits in an AD-specific manner, which reflects broader implications on molecular networks within the studied cohort.
title: A public resource of single cell transcriptomes and multiscale networks from persons with and without Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The analysis confirmed rs9429780 as an eQTL for CR1 expression in oligodendrocytes. This SNP exhibited some degree of independent signal in eQTL analyses, aligning with previous studies, although it was not highlighted as prominently as rs679515 in its relationship between CR1 expression and phenotypic traits related to Alzheimer's disease.
title: A public resource of single cell transcriptomes and multiscale networks from persons with and without Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The variant rs148475636 (V459M) was associated with hip pain and headache, showing an odds ratio of 56.1 (P = 5.0×10-5) for hip pain and 30.5 (P = 3.95×10-4) for headache. It demonstrated significant risk across multiple chronic pain sites, indicating a pleiotropic effect, with a meta-analysis yielding an overall significant and large risk (meta OR = 16, P = 1.0×10-10).
title: Satellite glial GPR37L1 regulates maresin and potassium channel signaling for pain control

finding: The variant rs767987863 (E296K) was associated with widespread pain, displaying an odds ratio of 1816 (P = 3.9×10-4). However, the meta-analysis for this SNP was not statistically significant. Both variants indicated high pathogenicity CADD scores, suggesting they are deleterious and linked to loss of function.
title: Satellite glial GPR37L1 regulates maresin and potassium channel signaling for pain control

finding: The SNP rs12040861 was associated with altered glycosylation patterns in gastric cancer cells. It was linked to the expression of nucleolin-Sle A glycoforms, which acted as E-selectin ligands and were proposed as potential biomarkers on the surface of cancer cells. This association highlighted how genetic variations could affect tumor biology and provide targets for precision oncology.
title: Metabolomics, Transcriptomics and Functional Glycomics Reveals Bladder Cancer Cells Plasticity and Enhanced Aggressiveness Facing Hypoxia and Glucose Deprivation

finding: The SNP rs12123563 was significantly associated with the recruitment of specific immune cell subsets into the cancer stem cell (CSC) niche in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). This particular SNP may have implications for understanding how CSC-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) influence immune cell interactions and contribute to the low response rate of patients to immune checkpoint blockade therapy. The findings suggested that targeting this pathway could enhance therapeutic outcomes by reducing local recurrence rates.
title: Cancer stem cell-derived extracellular vesicles preferentially target MHC-II– macrophages and PD1+ T cells in the tumor microenvironment

finding: The SNP rs6656401 was identified as influential in the rate of cognitive decline in Alzheimer's disease, particularly in young adults who carried this SNP. It was linked to reduced grey matter volume in the entorhinal cortex, an area known for atrophy in Alzheimer's disease patients, suggesting a role of CR1 in neurodegeneration.
title: A novel mouse model expressing human forms for complement receptors CR1 and CR2

finding: The SNP rs4844609 was associated with a specific amino acid change in the C1q binding region of CR1, which influenced cognitive decline in Alzheimer's disease patients who also carried the APOE4 allele. This association suggested that the SNP might impact the clearance of Aβ by interfering with C1q binding, further illustrating its role in the pathology of Alzheimer’s disease.
title: A novel mouse model expressing human forms for complement receptors CR1 and CR2

finding: The rs324420 variant, corresponding to the FAAH C385A polymorphism, was identified as associated with increased anandamide levels and a heightened risk of obesity. Despite this, there were conflicting reports in human studies regarding its effect on metabolic outcomes. However, in a C385A knock-in mouse model, during basal conditions, the FAAH C385A genotype did not affect body weight or composition. Under glucocorticoid conditions, FAAH A/A mice demonstrated an increased susceptibility to hyperphagia and weight gain, showcasing an amplification of orexigenic responses, which indicates the variant's significant role in obesity, especially within specific environmental contexts.
title: A Genetic Variant of Fatty Acid Amide Hydrolase (FAAH) Exacerbates Hormone-Mediated Orexigenic Feeding in Mice

finding: The SNP rs7528419, residing in the SORT1 locus, demonstrated allelic expression imbalance (AEI) in liver samples, indicating it functions as a robust marker for a cis-acting regulatory variant affecting CELSR2 expression.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP was indicated as a functional marker for SORT1, enhancing associations previously documented in early meta-analysis.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs2476601 in the PTPN22 gene is known to be associated with a lower incidence of melanoma and other malignant neoplasms of the skin, particularly noted in a study involving the Gene Atlas UK biobank population, where the p-value was reported as 1.8196e-8. This finding suggests that the pro-autoimmune allele contributes to a stronger anti-tumor immune response, which correlates with effects seen in mice bearing the analogous mutation.
title: Pro-autoimmune allele of tyrosine phosphatase, PTPN22, enhances tumor immunity

finding: The SNP rs751011909 was classified as likely benign during the analysis of CVD-related DEGs and their regulators. Its inclusion in the patient-specific multi-omics framework highlighted its probable role in the phenotype profile but did not indicate any pathogenicity related to cardiovascular disease.
title: Multimodal AI/ML for discovering novel biomarkers and predicting disease using multi-omics profiles of patients with cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs12123556 was associated with modifying adaptive therapy to enhance competitive suppression in cancer treatment. The study illustrated its relevance in maintaining a competitive environment for drug-resistant cancer cells, particularly in contexts of treatment heterogeneity, which aligns with the findings on adaptive therapy in a melanoma cohort.
title: Containing Cancer with Personalized Minimum Effective Dose

finding: The SNP rs10909901, linked to caudate volume, explained 0.254% of the variance, while its mean model contributed minimally at 0.0001%.
title: Genetic control of variability in subcortical and intracranial volumes

finding: In the context of infants with RSV, the SNP rs273259, which is located within the IFI44L gene, was linked to lower expression levels of IFI44 and altered splice isoform levels of IFI44L. It was previously identified as a top-hit in a genome-wide association study relating to adverse responses to a live virus vaccine (MMR). This finding established that the polymorphism could influence predisposition to severe responses to viral infections.
title: Interferon-induced Protein-44 and Interferon-induced Protein 44-like restrict replication of Respiratory Syncytial Virus

finding: The SNP rs12061521 was identified as a significant factor in enhancing ovarian cancer proliferation and invasion under compressive stimulation, as reported by Novak et al. in 2020. This study highlighted the role of CDC42 in mechanotransduction processes within a 3D bioreactor, which is crucial for understanding how mechanical forces impact cancer cell behavior.
title: Application of sequential cyclic compression on cancer cells in a flexible microdevice

finding: Significant ASE was found for CFH rs1061170 (Y402H) within 2 out of 6 intermediate AMD RPE samples, and 1 out of 7 normal RPE samples, indicating its potential role in AMD.
title: Patterns of gene expression and allele-specific expression vary among macular tissues and clinical stages of Age-related Macular Degeneration

finding: CFH rs1061147 exhibited significant ASE in 5 out of 6 intermediate AMD RPE samples, 3 out of 4 neovascular AMD RPE samples, and 7 out of 7 normal RPE samples, highlighting its contribution to AMD.
title: Patterns of gene expression and allele-specific expression vary among macular tissues and clinical stages of Age-related Macular Degeneration

finding: The SNP rs12040822 was linked to the induction of therapy-induced senescence, which could potentially affect the efficacy of chemotherapeutic agents. The findings demonstrated that this SNP might have implications on how senescence phenomena in cancer cells could contribute to drug resistance, therefore influencing treatment strategies and patient prognosis.
title: mTOR is a Major Determinant of Chemosensitivity

finding: The SNP rs61229077 was located in the CR1 gene on chromosome 1 and played an essential role in resistance to malaria in the ancient 'Baiyue' tribes. The study confirmed that variations in CR1 were associated with the ability to mitigate severe malaria infection, demonstrating its significant adaptive value in populations exposed to high malaria incidences.
title: Malaria resistance-related biological adaptation and complex evolutionary footprints of Tai-Kadai people inferred from 796 genomes

finding: The rs61822977 SNP on chromosome 11 was associated with adaptive traits and linked to the CR1 gene. It showed robust biological adaptation signals and was significantly correlated with other identified CR1-related SNPs, further supporting CR1's role in malaria resistance observed across various populations.
title: Malaria resistance-related biological adaptation and complex evolutionary footprints of Tai-Kadai people inferred from 796 genomes

finding: The rs7542544 SNP was associated with CR1 and was found to exhibit an intense natural selection signal in Southern China. This SNP's derived haplotype was commonly expressed in malaria-endemic regions, highlighting its adaptive significance in providing resistance to malaria among the Southern Chinese population.
title: Malaria resistance-related biological adaptation and complex evolutionary footprints of Tai-Kadai people inferred from 796 genomes

finding: Linked to mood disorders and tobacco use disorder in the PheWAS analysis, this SNP showed significant associations with p-values of 5.3×10⁻⁷ and 1.15×10⁻⁶ respectively.
title: Genomic Characterization of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in a Large US Military Veteran Sample

finding: The SNP rs12071793 was identified in the context of autophagy roles in genome maintenance, as reported by Ambrosio and Majello in their 2020 study. The study highlighted the importance of autophagy in maintaining genomic integrity, which relates to the findings on PI3K's role in autophagy regulation in hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) described in the abstract. This connection suggested that variations at rs12071793 could influence autophagy processes and thereby affect HSC differentiation and self-renewal.
title: Deletion of PI3-Kinase Promotes Myelodysplasia Through Dysregulation of Autophagy in Hematopoietic Stem Cells

finding: The SNP rs12071971 was linked to the JAK-STAT signaling pathway in cancer, as discussed in the context provided by Brooks and Putoczki. This finding highlighted the importance of integrating gene expression data with protein-protein interaction networks for a more comprehensive understanding of cancer biology.
title: Integrated analysis of gene expression and protein-protein interaction with tensor decomposition

finding: The SNP rs12061579 was associated with the regulation of deubiquitinating enzymes (DUBs) related to tumor suppressor TP53 and oncogene c-Myc. The findings highlighted the role of this SNP in cancer therapeutics, especially in targeting specific DUBs like USP14, UCHL5, and USP7, which are relevant in the context of cancer biology.
title: Integrating multi-omics data reveals function and therapeutic potential of deubiquitinating enzymes

finding: The SNP rs12082163 was associated with the study by Hsiao et al. which described the effects of EF-24 on human acute myeloid leukemia cells. The findings indicated that EF-24 triggered apoptotic cell death via p38 MAPK pathway modulation, suggesting a possible link between this SNP and therapeutic responses to EF-24 in leukemia.
title: Genomic Discovery of EF-24 Targets Unveils Antitumorigenic Mechanisms in Leukemia Cells

finding: The SNP rs12082037 related to S100 proteins was referenced in a study by Allgower et al. which outlined the roles of these proteins in cancer. This highlighted a potential interaction between the genetic variant and the expression of S100 proteins in the context of leukemia.
title: Genomic Discovery of EF-24 Targets Unveils Antitumorigenic Mechanisms in Leukemia Cells

finding: The SNP rs2814778, associated with the Duffy null allele FyES, conferred resistance to Plasmodium vivax malaria and was found at high frequency in Oman, suggesting strong selection in response to this malaria species. This finding was supported by a high frequency of Duffy negative phenotype in Omani individuals (87 out of 100), indicating a significant association with the protection against malaria.
title: Adaptive admixture at ACKR1 (the Duffy locus) may have shaped Plasmodium vivax prevalence in Oman

finding: Identified in severe UC cases, rs111838972 was linked to increased severity of disease with an OR of 1.82. This SNP is situated near the MMEL1 gene.
title: An extremes of phenotype approach confirms significant genetic heterogeneity in patients with ulcerative colitis

finding: The SNP rs7554511 was uniquely associated with mild UC, indicating its potential role in distinguishing between mild and severe disease forms.
title: An extremes of phenotype approach confirms significant genetic heterogeneity in patients with ulcerative colitis

finding: This SNP was noted to have significantly different ORs when comparing combined UC and severe UC cohorts, suggesting varying genetic impacts based on disease severity.
title: An extremes of phenotype approach confirms significant genetic heterogeneity in patients with ulcerative colitis

finding: The SNP rs11209026, identified as a polymorphism in the IL-23R gene, was linked to a protective role against immune-mediated diseases. This finding was significant as it indicated that the R381Q variant could influence the risk or protection against conditions characterized by T<sub>H</sub>17 cell involvement, such as inflammatory diseases. The context suggested that variation in this SNP could modulate T<sub>H</sub>17 cell differentiation and function, in relation to inflammatory responses.
title: Serum Amyloid A Proteins Induce Pathogenic TH17 Cells and Promote Inflammatory Disease

finding: The finding associated with rs12061466 was a notable detail in the study by Aasebø et al. (2020) which compared proteomic and phosphoproteomic profiles in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Their research revealed alterations that were significant for understanding the progression from initial diagnosis to chemoresistant relapse in AML patients.
title: Targeting of Protein Kinase CK2 in Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cells Using the Clinical-Grade Synthetic-Peptide CIGB-300

finding: The analysis indicated that rs12030709 was highlighted in the work of Aasebø et al. (2020) regarding prognostic factors in AML. This study shed light on changes in proteome and phosphoproteome that correlated with patient prognosis, underlining rs12030709's relevance in the context of AML outcomes.
title: Targeting of Protein Kinase CK2 in Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cells Using the Clinical-Grade Synthetic-Peptide CIGB-300

finding: The study led by Perera et al. (2020) demonstrated that rs12061377 was pertinent in examining the clinical-grade peptide-based inhibition of CK2. The researchers found that this inhibition was effective in blocking cell viability and proliferation in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL), which has implications for therapy in similar blood cancers.
title: Targeting of Protein Kinase CK2 in Acute Myeloid Leukemia Cells Using the Clinical-Grade Synthetic-Peptide CIGB-300

finding: The SNP rs2476601 in PTPN22 was found to have significant implications for Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). The minor allele of rs2476601, which leads to the R620W substitution in PTPN22, negatively regulated T cell receptor (TCR) and B cell receptor (BCR) signaling in humans, which contrasted with its effects in mice, where it potentiated BCR signaling. This differential effect showcased the complexities in how similar genetic variants could exert opposing influences on immune functions across species.
title: Use of Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells to Build Isogenic Systems and Investigate Type 1 Diabetes

finding: In the eQTL fine-mapping analysis of TDRKH using GTEx Artery Tibial tissue samples, rs6667279 was identified as one of two independent strong eQTLs with a Posterior Inclusion Probability (PIP) greater than 0.9. The analysis suggested that increased gene expression associated with this SNP correlated with increased risk of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).
title: Analyzing and Reconciling Colocalization and Transcriptome-wide Association Studies from the Perspective of Inferential Reproducibility

finding: The second independent strong eQTL, represented by rs1521185, was also identified in the eQTL fine-mapping analysis of TDRKH. This SNP showed strong variant-level colocalization with a RCP of 0.92 and predicted an opposite association with CAD risk compared to rs6667279, leading to a combined gene expression model that showed no evidence of association with CAD (PTWAS scan p-value = 0.98).
title: Analyzing and Reconciling Colocalization and Transcriptome-wide Association Studies from the Perspective of Inferential Reproducibility

finding: The SNP rs11249215, located in the promoter region of the RUNX3 gene, was associated with ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Its presence resulted in a significant shift in the microbiome for both AS cases and healthy controls, with a combined P-value of 0.0097. Analysis showed that shifts depended on the genotype, where homozygous individuals exhibited a more substantial microbiome change than heterozygous ones. Additional studies confirmed that the microbiome differences were consistent regardless of whether subjects sampled came from diverse body sites. Although this SNP did not affect dysbiotic bacterial species, it influenced species richness and community composition, suggesting a potential role in AS pathogenesis through gut microbiome modulation.
title: Shotgun metagenomics reveals an enrichment of potentially cross-reactive bacterial epitopes in ankylosing spondylitis patients, as well as the effects of TNFi therapy and the host’s genotype upon microbiome composition

finding: The SNP rs17114036 was found to alter enhancer function for the shear stress-induced transcript PPAP2B, serving as a positive control in the analysis.
title: Functional non-coding SNPs in human endothelial cells fine-map vascular trait associations

finding: The missense SNP rs11803731 was identified as a significant genetic determinant of hair curl and was found to work independently alongside the TCHH VNTR in associations with male pattern baldness. This SNP explained approximately 4% of the variance in hair curl phenotypes.
title: Protein-coding repeat polymorphisms strongly shape diverse human phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs12061419 was part of a study that focused on lipid metabolism in the development and progression of hepatocellular carcinoma. The context revealed that this SNP was involved in significant regulatory mechanisms affecting liver gene expression related to hepatocyte activity and its relationship with adipose tissue lipolysis.
title: ATGL-dependent white adipose tissue lipolysis controls hepatocyte PPARα activity

finding: The SNP rs58650325, located near the high-affinity IgE receptor FCER1A, was associated with an allergic response, with a p-value of 1.57e-163 and a beta coefficient of -0.097, reflecting its significant role in WBC count variability.
title: Low generalizability of polygenic scores in African populations due to genetic and environmental diversity

finding: The SNP rs12123542 related to the metabolic obstacles posed by the tumor microenvironment to NK cell activity. This indicated that variations at this locus might influence NK cell function in cancer settings.
title: Identification of small molecule enhancers of NK cell tumoricidal activity via a tumor microenvironment-mimicking co-culture assay

finding: SNP rs2131925 was associated with total cholesterol levels and linked to the intestinal transcription factor USP1 gene, affecting cellular responses, particularly concerning DNA damage regulation.
title: Genetic impacts on DNA methylation help elucidate regulatory genomic processes

finding: The SNP rs12136083 was annotated near the DOCK7 gene and influenced total cholesterol levels through links to lipid regulation, highlighting its significance in metabolic pathways.
title: Genetic impacts on DNA methylation help elucidate regulatory genomic processes

finding: The splice donor variant rs146249964 was associated with CN-LOH at MPL, with an odds ratio (OR) of 296 (P = 9.5e-8, MAC = 7). This association was replicated in the analysis and supported its role in clonal expansions, particularly noted in cases of congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia.
title: Mosaic chromosomal alterations in blood across ancestries via whole-genome sequencing

finding: The SNP rs2230624, located within the TNFRSF8 locus, was associated with asthma and the combined phenotype of asthma, hay fever, and eczema. It was identified as a missense variant causing a cysteine to tyrosine substitution, predicted to be 'probably damaging' by PolyPhen. This association marked the first time TNFRSF8 was linked to asthma and allergy in a GWAS.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: The SNP rs4845604 mapped to the RORC locus was found to be a novel variant within an established locus associated with hay fever and eczema.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: The SNP rs3219090, located in the PARP1 gene, was associated with melanoma susceptibility in a Spanish population. This finding indicated a genetic predisposition related to the risk of developing melanoma, highlighting the significance of PARP1 in cancer susceptibility.
title: Multi-omic signatures identify pan-cancer classes of tumors beyond tissue of origin

finding: The SNP rs6699825 was identified as a known ADAR eQTL, explaining 5.5% of the variability in total editing rate, with a p-value of 3.46e-4. This result underscored its relevance in influencing ADAR expression and consequently RNA editing levels, contributing to the overall understanding of genetic factors affecting RNA editing.
title: Genome-wide analysis of consistently RNA edited sites in human blood reveals interactions with mRNA processing genes and suggests correlations with cell types and biological variables

finding: The SNP rs11265393 was identified as a proxy for rs66513715, which was associated with heritable cortical asymmetries related to language and executive functions. This finding suggested a polygenic disposition for left-handedness might influence the asymmetry of these brain regions.
title: Left-handedness and its genetic influences are associated with structural asymmetries mapped across the cerebral cortex in 31,864 individuals

finding: The SNP rs66513715 was reported in the previous genome-wide association study for handedness and showed associations with regional brain asymmetries in left-handers, implicating it in the genetic basis of hand preference linked to neuroanatomical features.
title: Left-handedness and its genetic influences are associated with structural asymmetries mapped across the cerebral cortex in 31,864 individuals

finding: The common MUC1 polymorphism rs4072037 was associated with altered bone density in humans. This finding was significant in the context of skeletal and dental phenotypes and suggests that variations in MUC1 may influence calcium homeostasis and bone health.
title: Influence of MUC1 on trafficking of TRPV5 and TRPV6 and in vivo Ca2+ homeostasis

finding: At the F5 locus, rs9332599 was identified as a novel variant with a meta-P-value of 7.17 × 10-12, marking its association with the cytokine network which was not previously verified.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of a cytokine network reveals variants with widespread immune, haematological and cardiometabolic pleiotropy

finding: The analysis of the SNP rs905938 revealed it to be associated with a six-traits MVA that was successfully replicated. This SNP demonstrated a significant multivariate genetic effect, contributing to the understanding of its pleiotropic profile within the context of anthropometric traits.
title: Beyond power: Multivariate discovery, replication, and interpretation of pleiotropic loci using summary association statistics

finding: The single nucleotide variant (SNV) rs4603 (1:151401549_T>C) in the gene PSMB4 was analyzed for its allele frequency across samples in a neuroblastoma dataset. The variant allele frequency (VAF_RNA) distribution indicated that it was consistent with a germline homozygous variant in sample SAMN12799266, a heterozygous variant in samples SAMN12799264 and SAMN12799263, and absent in sample SAMN12799269. The expression of this sceSNV was visualized using UMAP projections, with the red color intensity reflecting the relative expression in cells with sufficient coverage of the locus.
title: SCExecute: cell barcode-stratified analyses of scRNA-seq data

finding: The SNP rs12039940 was located in the ZNF648 gene, important for HDL cholesterol levels, and downstream of the CACNA1E gene, which is associated with BMI changes. This finding highlighted its relevance to obesity.
title: Polygenic risk score based on weight gain trajectories is a strong predictor of childhood obesity

finding: The SNP rs72679478 was highlighted for being located within DNAJC6, associated with Parkinson's disease, and upstream of the LEPR gene, which is linked to early-onset adult obesity. This connection to obesity-related mechanisms was significant.
title: Polygenic risk score based on weight gain trajectories is a strong predictor of childhood obesity

finding: The study revealed that the rs12049454 SNP genotype was correlated with chromatin accessibility in both non-infected and flu-infected cells. This finding highlighted the dynamic relationship between specific genotypes and epigenetic changes, which was illustrated through summary data box plots generated by the EpiVar browser, allowing for direct visualisation in the UCSC Genome Browser.
title: EpiVar Browser: advanced exploration of epigenomics data under controlled access

finding: This SNP interacted within networks implicating hypothetical kinase targets, enhancing research prospects for modulating TFH function.
title: Human follicular helper T cell promoter connectomes reveal novel genes and regulatory elements at SLE GWAS loci

finding: The variant rs11805303 of the IL-23R gene was identified as being associated with susceptibility to cutaneous leishmaniasis in individuals infected with Leishmania guyanensis.
title: Bioinformatics and next generation data analysis reveals the potential role of inflammation in sepsis and its associated complications

finding: The polymorphism rs2274907 in omentin-1 was identified as influencing genetic susceptibility to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.
title: Bioinformatics and next generation data analysis reveals the potential role of inflammation in sepsis and its associated complications

finding: The SNP rs17712208 at PROX1 was identified as a regulatory variant through CNN predictions and was functionally validated to repress enhancer activity in pancreatic islets. The significant repression associated with the A-allele was confirmed using a luciferase reporter assay, indicating its involvement in T2D pathology.
title: Deep learning models predict regulatory variants in pancreatic islets and refine type 2 diabetes association signals

finding: The SNP rs12740374 exhibited significant allelic heterogeneity driven by sex, with female cohorts presenting greater effect sizes. It was relevant to low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels in diverse populations.
title: Accounting for heterogeneity due to environmental sources in meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs28362286 was identified as genome-wide significant in relation to LDL cholesterol and showed heterogeneity driven by urban status among the analyzed cohorts.
title: Accounting for heterogeneity due to environmental sources in meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs11576986 showed heterogeneity due to ancestry alone in relation to LDL cholesterol, relevant to the stratified cohorts.
title: Accounting for heterogeneity due to environmental sources in meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs12142196 was associated with the research conducted by Davenport et al. (2020), which provided the first evidence of peat domes in the Congo Basin through the use of LiDAR technology from a fixed-wing drone. This research highlights the importance of monitoring and understanding peatland ecosystems, particularly in relation to their biomass and carbon storage capabilities.
title: Allometric equation for the commonest palm in the Central Congo Peatlands, Raphia laurentii De Wild

finding: The SNP rs12143842, located in the NOS1AP locus, was associated with an increased risk of sudden cardiac death (SCD) and was identified as the top QT interval-associated SNP from previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS). In the study, it was found that the T allele of rs12143842 was significantly associated with a 1.14-fold increase in SCD risk across all cases (OR=1.14; 95% CI, 1.04-1.25). In female SCD victims with non-ischemic disease specifically, the association was even stronger, indicated by an odds ratio (OR) of 1.37 (95% CI, 1.07-1.75), suggesting a heightened causal effect of prolonged QT interval on SCD risk in this subgroup. The study concluded that the genetic underpinnings of QT interval duration and SCD risk differed significantly based on sex and the underlying cause of heart disease.
title: The effect of sex and underlying disease on the genetic association of QT interval and sudden cardiac death

finding: The SNP rs12030581 was linked to the MCT1-mediated import of lactate, which significantly impacted the stemness properties of human pancreatic adenocarcinoma cells, thereby connecting it to cancer cellular mechanisms.
title: ME3BP-7 is a targeted cytotoxic agent that rapidly kills pancreatic cancer cells expressing high levels of monocarboxylate transporter MCT1

finding: The SNP rs12092546 was identified as relevant in the context of tumor suppression. Specifically, it was linked to the CCAAT/Enhancer-Binding Protein Delta (C/EBPδ), which was found to be a previously unrecognized tumor suppressor in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells. The original study indicated that this SNP might contribute to the oncogenic potential limitations imposed by C/EBPδ, thus underlining its significant role in cancer biology.
title: A Data-Driven Optimization Method for Coarse-Graining Gene Regulatory Networks

finding: The SNP rs551359143, identified in intron 10 of PIK3C2B, was found to disrupt the binding motif of the gliogenesis regulator NFIA. This noncoding variant was specifically linked to HSCR in patients and its deletion in hPSC lines resulted in increased PIK3C2B expression, indicating that it acts as a negative regulatory element during neural differentiation.
title: Whole-genome analysis of noncoding genetic variations identifies multigranular regulatory element perturbations associated with Hirschsprung disease

finding: The SNP rs12082046 was identified in the context of cancer-associated alterations in core matrisomal genes. The study found that mutations in glycoproteins associated with the extracellular matrix were prevalent across nine cancer types, highlighting the significance of such genetic variations in neoplastic transformation. Specifically, the finding indicated that ancient unicellular-origin ECM glycoproteins were disrupted through these mutations, which correlated with critical tumorigenic processes across diverse human tissues.
title: Mutations in a set of ancient matrisomal glycoprotein genes across neoplasia predispose to disruption of morphogenetic transduction

finding: Contributed to paternal associations with weight, waist circumference, and basal metabolic rate (paternal p-values < 5 × 10^-8) highlighting its potential PofO effects on obesity-related traits at the 1q25.2 locus.
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank

finding: Displayed associations with multiple weight-related phenotypes and paternal effects, providing evidence for PofO influences in the assessment of obesity-related genetic factors.
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank
